one_reviews_text: The setup process is the easiest out there just plug the two cables and install the oculus software and you are ready to play vr games. The increase in the display resolution is very noticeable and text is readable now the decrease in refresh rate from 90Hz to 80Hz isn't noticeable at all. In terms of tracking it's good enough and will do the job, it's very light dependent it struggles in tracking when it's in dark environments and very bright environments (direct sunlight). Last thing the audio quality isn't that good and over the ear headphones dont fit because the halo strap is a bit too thick unless you have a very large headphones or use in ear headphones
review_date: Reviewed in the United Arab Emirates on 26 August 2019
review_title: Easy and simple to use, but lacks audio quality

one_reviews_text: Must get don't think too much be sure you have display port in your GPU and 3.1 usb port and you run VR test application before you buy it ... Sadly no Oculus Rift S Optical Cable replacement in market

one_reviews_text: Comparison vs. original Rift.VISUALS are much better.  The improvements in optics and resolution and much more than a modern console generation leap.  Bigger sweet spot, clearer text, all but no screen door effect.  It is a much bigger improvement than I expected.COMFORT greatly improved.  This is a personal thing and in fact I wasn't sure the first time I put it on, but one you spend some time in understanding the adjustments, it completely takes the weight of your face and the weight distribution is the best of any headset I've tried.  Wearing large glasses is a none issue, works comfortably and much easier to get on and off than original Rift.TRACKING is a long subject, but I love the new inside out tracking.  No external sensors required and everything is tracked, including the controllers, by the 5 built in cameras on the headset.  :UPDATE: with a new update, Oculus have performed some sorcercy that makes tracking nie on perfect. You are now able to bring controller right up and touch the headset without issue and deadsorts are now completeoy a non-issue in game.:PRIOR TO UPDATE There are dead spots behind you back if you try to find them, but I never found this a problem in games.  If touching the controllers to the headset, tracking can get "moments", so I found I hold my guns an inch further away than I previously did in FPS, which was an easy adjustment.  On original Rift I had occasional wobbles with the controllers where with the S I no longer get that at all.  Which makes sense as the tracking cameras are <1m from the controllers as opposed to up to 3m previously.AUDIO is not as high quality sounding as original Rift.  This is because there is no on-ear headphones and instead audio is pumped down the band to over having anything over your ears.  I think most people would prefer the original solution but I am actually a fan of it.  It getting in and out of the headset for glasses wear much easier and it's more comfortable.  Also is nice to have the choice on whether to be isolated or not.  I found if I want high quality audio and isolation from sounds in the outside world my standard pair of over-ear headphones worth fine using a 10-20cm 3.5mm cable (can be longer but dangles).  But I find positional audio very good from the in-built speaker and rarely use the headphones.SETUP AND PASSTHROUGH+ is excellent.  Setup takes less than 5 minutes.  On the PC you run install, has a couple of optional videos but then all of setup is inside the headset.  This is doable as a feature you get with Rift S is passthrough+ which allows you to see a black and white AR view of your surroundings.  This is low res but is an excellent feature as allows you to see the real world whenever you want a the double tap of a button.  During setup this is the first thing you see as it allows you to use you controllers as laser pointers and draw your guardian.  The view is stereo corrected, so everything appears where it should be.  Additionally, when playing a game, if you walk up to the edge of your Guardian boundary, (a mesh appears as an overlay when head of controllers are near it) and you put your head through it, it fades to the real world, which is very cool and handy.CONS - as mentioned, if wanting excellent audio with convenience, this is a step down for some.  The headset doesn't tilt like the OG Rift, I've got used to this but missed it at first. IPD is only software adjustable, so if you have a outer percentile IPD (distance between your pupils) they try before you buy.  Cable feels a little heavier than on OG Rift, though might be because I have a Quest too now, which has no cable.  None of these things come anywhere near enough to not make me not thoroughly recommend the Rift S with 5 star rating.NB - Rift S cable is a meter longer than OG Rift, now at 5m.  Additional i found the following two cables work well if you want to extend another ~2m):https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B01KRLQG2M/ - Rankie DP Extension Cable, 1.8m DisplayPort Male to Femalehttps://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00P0ES0YE - Ugreen USB3 Extension
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 24 May 2019
review_title: Big upgrade to Original Oculus Rift CV1

one_reviews_text:
Wichtiges Update 15.09.2020:Diese Rezension wies bisher 5 Sterne für die Rift S aus. Was die Hardware angeht, bleibe ich auch dabei. Das neueste Update der Geschäfts- und Datenschutzbedingungen sowie die Facebook-Pflicht für Neukäufer ändert meine Ansicht aber grundlegend. Vor allem, da Oculus nach der Facebook-Übernahme noch öffentlich versprach, dass ein Facebook-Account nicht notwendig sei.Bestehende Nutzer wie ich werden zwar nicht zum Umstieg auf einen Facebook-Account gezwungen, allerdings kündigte Oculus schon an, dass ab 2023 nicht mehr die vollständige Funktionalität ohne Facebook-Account bereitgestellt wird. Zudem geht die Datenverarbeitung offiziell an Facebook über. Das obwohl Facebook eigentlich laut diverser Urteile gar keine Daten zwischen seinen Konzerngesellschaften so einfach teilen darf. Zum Zeitpunkt dieses Updates wurde der Verkauf der Oculus-Geräte in Deutschland gar ausgesetzt, mutmaßlich vorauseilend im Zusammenhang mit einem Urteil, der die Kopplung von Produkten (z.B. WhatsApp oder Rift S mit Facebook-Account) verbietet.Jeder muss für sich persönlich entscheiden, was ihm seine Daten wert sind. Daher: Wer kein Problem mit der Datenkrake Facebook hat, kann immer noch bedenkenlos zugreifen. Persönlich rate ich jedoch jedem davon ab, allein schon um diese Praktiken nicht zu unterstützen. Ich persönlich werde die Konsequenzen ziehen und keine Oculus-Produkte mehr kaufen.1. Kurzfazit:Diese Rezension ist recht lang geraten, da mir das Thema VR am Herzen liegt. Daher ist das “Kurz”fazit auch etwas ausführlicher als bei meinen anderen Rezensionen.Zusammenfassend spreche ich der Rift S eine Kaufempfehlung aus, besonders für Einsteiger, die nicht beliebig viel Geld investieren wollen, aber schon über einen ausreichend starken PC verfügen. Kein anderes Headset am Markt bietet für diesen Preis eine solch ausgewogene Kombination aus guter Bildqualität, sehr solidem Tracking, Benutzerfreundlichkeit und Softwareauswahl. Daher vergebe ich auch 5 Sterne obwohl ich durchaus mehrere Kritikpunkte sehe (Details weiter unten im Review).Das heisst nicht, dass die Rift S perfekt oder für jeden geeignet ist. VR-Enthusiasten ohne Budgetbeschränkung werden wohl eher mit der 
HTC Vive
 oder der bald erscheinenden Valve Index glücklich. Für VR-Einsteiger die keinen Spiele-PC besitzen, mag die 
PSVR
 eine gute Alternative sein. Diese bietet mit niedrigeren Gesamtkosten auch ein tolles Erlebnis. (Dies war auch mein Einstieg in die VR-Welt.) Ganz kabellos kann man auch mit der 
Quest
 unterwegs sein. Die gute Nachricht ist: Es gibt eine ganze Fülle von Alternativen. Für mich persönlich ist die Rift S momentan die beste Wahl.Updates:1. Tracking funktioniert auch bei anspruchsvollen Spielen wirklich gut (z.B. Beatsaber im Expert-Modus ausgiebig getestet).2. Manche Nutzer klagen über kurzzeitiges Bildflackern, Tracking-Aussetzer etc. Bei mir war das nicht der Fall, aber in der Community wird dazu geraten, die Kabelverbindung am Headset zu überprüfen. Diese kann sich wohl beim Transport lösen.3. Ich hatte nun auch Verbindungsprobleme: Schwarzes Bild, die Oculus App zeigt fehlende Displayportverbindung an. Lösung: Rift S komplett trennen, USB an (3.0) Port anstecken, ca. 5-10s warten, bis die Oculus App die Rift wieder erkennt, dann erst das Displayport-Kabel mit der Grafikkarte verbinden. Hoffentlich kommt da bald ein Patch.Besonders gut überlegen sollten sich die Anschaffung potentielle Käufer die:- einen Pupillenabstand (IPD) von mehr als 65mm haben (siehe weiter unten).- die absolute beste Bildqualität am Markt wollen.- das absolut beste Tracking am Markt wollen.- keine Facebook-Produkte wollen (einen Facebook-Account braucht man zwar nicht, aber Oculus wurde von der Datenkrake aufgekauft).Sollte einer dieser Punkte zutreffen, ist vielleicht eine der oben genannten Alternativen die bessere Wahl.2. Bewegungserkennung - Tracking:Manch einer fragt bei VR-Lösungen zuerst nach der Bildqualität. Mir persönlich ist die Bewegungserkennung, das sogenannte Tracking, deutlich wichtiger. Das mag auch daran liegen, dass ich selbst im Forschungs-Bereich Computer Vision schon an solchen Themen gearbeitet habe. Aber auch ohne fachliches Interesse ist es für ein glaubwürdiges und angenehmes VR-Erlebnis sehr wichtig, dass sowohl die Kopfbewegungen als auch die Bewegungen der Controller akkurat wiedergegeben werden. Dies ist zum Beispiel eine der ganz großen Schwächen der PSVR, welche noch die guten alten Move Controller der PS3-Ära verwendet.Grundsätzlich gibt es zwei Möglichkeiten für Tracking: Externes Tracking verwendet eine oder mehrere Kameras, die den Nutzer von aussen filmen und die Bewegungen von Markierungen auf dem Headset oder den Controllern nachverfolgen. Das kann sehr gut funktionieren (z.B. mit dem Lighthouse-System der HTC Vive, mehreren Kameras wie bei der Original Oculus Rift) oder auch weniger gut (z.B. mit einer einzelnen Kamera und wenig Rechenpower bei PSVR). Die Rift S hingegen verwendet “Inside-out-Tracking”: Kameras auf dem Headset filmen die Umgebung und die Controller und schätzen hierdurch die Bewegungen des Nutzers. Bisher wurde diese Art des Trackings primär von den sogenannten WMR-Headsets (Windows Mixed Reality) eingesetzt. Da keine Sensoren im Zimmer verteilt werden müssen ist sie einfacher einzurichten und verursacht weniger Chaos. Allerdings war auch das Controller-Tracking oft schlecht: Bei aktiven Kopfbewegungen verschwinden die Controller gerne aus dem Blickfeld - was bedeutet dass sie nicht weiter verfolgt werden können. Die internen Lage und Bewegungssensoren, wie sie auch in vielen Handys zu finden sind, können dies teilweise kompensieren, aber nicht komplett.Die gute Nachricht: Das Tracking der Rift S ist wirklich sehr gut! Durch 5 Kameras wird fast das komplette Umfeld ständig erfasst. Bei meinen bisherigen Tests musste ich mich schon sehr anstrengen um hinter dem Rücken das Tracking zu verlieren. Im Spielealltag sollte dies kaum einen Unterschied machen. Ein gutes Lighthouse Setup bei der Vive oder Index mag zwar besser sein, zumindest für meine Zwecke ist das Tracking vollkommen ausreichend.Weiterer Vorteil des Inside-Out-Trackings: Eine Passthrough-Option, mit der man mit aufgesetztem Headset auch per Knopfdruck seine Umgebung wahrnehmen kann. Diese ist zwar nur schwarz-weiss und hat eine leichte Verzögerung, die Rift S rechnet sie allerdings in eine recht akkurate 3-D Darstellung um. So kann man z.B. leicht nach seinem Glas Wasser greifen um einen Schluck zu trinken. Zudem vereinfacht das Passthrough die Einrichtung des Spielbereichs merklich. Man setzt das Headset auf und zeichnet mit einigen simplen Controllerbewegungen den hindernisfreien Bereich einfach auf den Boden. Danach warnt die Rift automatisch vor Unfallgefahr, indem sie die Grenzen in der virtuellen Welt als Gitter anzeigt, sobald man ihnen zu nahe kommt. Das kann z.B. die Vive zwar auch, allerdings ist die Definition des Spielbereichs viel komplizierter, da man mangels Passthrough das Headset dabei nicht tragen kann.Hinweis: Bei schlechtem Tracking muss nicht unbedingt das Gerät kaputt sein. Schlechte Lichtverhältnisse können zu Problemen führen, sowohl bei zu dunklen Räumen als auch bei direkter Sonneneinstrahlung.3. Bildqualität:Zur Ankündigung der Rift S gab es einen großen Aufschrei in der VR-Gemeinde. Die Auflösung wurde im Vergleich zur Original Rift lediglich von 1080×1200 auf 1280 x 1440 Bildpunkte pro Auge erhöht. Zudem wurden zwei getrennte OLED-Displays durch ein einzelnes TFT-Display ersetzt, welches auch noch über eine niedrigere Bildwiederholrate verfügt. Zum Vergleich: HP bringt bald ein Headset mit 2160 x 2160 pro Auge heraus. Diese Entscheidungen wurden von VR-Fans in Diskussionsforen hart kritisiert.Meine persönliche Meinung: Es gibt viele Faktoren, die wichtiger sind als die reinen technischen Daten. Ja, das TFT-Display hat grundsätzlich schlechtere Schwarzwerte als ein OLED-Display. Dafür zieht es aber auch keine Schlieren bei hellen Bildpunkten. Ja, die Auflösung der Rift S ist nicht viel besser als bei ihrem Vorgänger. Dennoch ist die Bildqualität deutlich gestiegen: Der sogenannte Fliegengitter-Effekt (engl. SDE) ist fast verschwunden! In Headsets der ersten Generation betrachtete man die Welt durch ein wahrnehmbares Gitter zwischen den einzelnen Bildpunkten. Dies resultiert vor allem aus den Konfigurationen sogenannter Subpixel, die für die einzelnen Farben (rot, grün, blau) verantwortlich sind. Schon die PSVR bot trotz eines prinzipiell schlechteren und billigeren Displays eine gute Bildqualität, da dieser SDE weniger signifikant ausfiel als bei der Original Rift.Zudem wurden die Linsen verbessert. Sogenannte “god rays” (zu deutsch deutlich undramatischer “Strahlenbüschel”), Überstrahleffekte die aus Linsenreflektionen entstehen, sind ebenfalls reduziert. Dies ist allerdings ein durchaus subjektiver Eindruck. Ich persönlich nehme bei sehr hellen objekten auf dunklem Grund solche Überstrahleffekte war, was allerdings vielleicht auch durch meine Hornhautkrümmung  begünstigt sein kann. (Ich nehme solche Effekte auch in 2D war).Die Rift S bietet vielleicht nicht die absolut beste Bildqualität, doch ich bin damit vollends zufrieden und konnte z.B. einen deutlichen Qualitätssprung verglichen mit PSVR feststellen. Ein zusätzlicher “Vorteil” der relativ niedrigen Auflösung und Bildwiederholrate ist auch die Auswirkung auf die Hardwareanforderung. Weniger Bildpunkte benötigen auch weniger Leistung. Mit einer Mittelklassekarte der aktuellen oder letzten Generation ist man gut bedient. Ich betreibe eine GTX 1070 und bin sehr zufrieden. Selbst mit einer alten GTX 770 liefen viele der genügsameren VR-Demos übrigens  immer noch flüssig, obwohl diese weit unter den Mindestanforderungen liegt.  Ich empfehle allerdings, sich an die Mindestanforderungen der Oculus-Homepage zu halten.4. Ergonomie:Headset: Man merkt der Rift S an, dass Oculus diesmal mit Lenovo kooperiert hat. Sony hat das PSVR-Design mit einem soliden Kopfband, welches das Gewicht des Headsets trägt nämlich an Lenovo lizensiert. Diese Handschrift findet sich auch bei der Rift S wieder, was ich als Vorteil sehe: Das Headset drückt nicht auf’s Gesicht und bleibt auch bei längerer Tragedauer recht bequem. Sowohl das Kopfband selbst, der Stell-Riemen überkopf, als auch das Headset selbst lassen sich anpassen. Dennoch ist jede Kopfform anders und jeder muss für sich selbst ausprobieren, ob dieses System bequem ist. Ein ergonomischer Nachteil ergibt sich jedoch durch das in Abschnitt 2 erwähnte neue Display: Der Pupillenabstand kann nicht mehr mechanisch reguliert werden. Bei der alten Rift konnten hier die beiden OLED-Displays einfach näher zueinander oder weiter weg geschoben werden.  Mit einem Einzeldisplay ist das natürlich nicht möglich. Per Software lässt sich zwar das Bild verschieben, doch das hilft nur bedingt. Mit recht genau 65mm habe ich keine Probleme, wer jedoch ausserhalb des empfohlenen Bereichs von 61.5mm - 65.5mm liegt, muss testen, ob das Bild noch klar zu erkennen ist und der 3-D-Effekt funktioniert. Hier kann es zu verschwommenen Bildern, falscher Größenwahrnehmung oder sogar Doppelbildern kommen.Controller: Im Grunde handelt es sich um die altbewährten Touch-Controller die man schon von der alten Rift kennt. Lediglich die Tracker-Ringe sind wegen des neuen Systems nach oben gewandert. Ich finde sie sehr bequem, vor allem da man sie zwischendurch auch einmal loslassen kann und sie dann fröhlich an der Handgelenkschlaufe baumeln, bis man sie wieder braucht. Zudem erkennen sie die Position von Daumen und Zeigefinger separat, was eine rudimentäre Handsimulation erlaubt. So kann man in VR recht wirklichkeitsnah Objekte greifen, Knöpfe bedienen oder einfache Gesten vollführen.5. Softwareangebot:Was kann man nun mit der Rift S machen? So ziemlich alles was am Markt verfügbar ist! Leider gibt es auch in VR die Unsitte von Exklusivtiteln, was an sich eine ärgerliche Sache ist. Mit der Rift S kann man jedoch ohne größere Umwege sowohl die Programme aus dem Oculus-Store als auch von Steam benutzen. Nicht alle SteamVR-Apps funktionieren gleich gut, aber dennoch hat man ein riesiges Softwareangebot von umfangreichen Spielen über Minispielchen, “Erlebnisse” (z.B. BBC-VR-Dokus), Videoplayer mit Kino-Feeling (Riesenleinwand), Desktopbedienung, 3-D-Malprogramme und so weiter…Aussen vor bleiben natürlich Sony-Exklusivtitel für PSVR wie das grandiose 
Astrobot
. Auch bedeutet das riesige Angebot auf dem PC nicht unbedingt auch immer gute Qualität. Der Playstation-VR-Markt ist durchaus besser “kuratiert” und es gibt weniger Schrott, den man vermeiden sollte. Dennoch finde ich, dass der PC hier seine Stärken ausspielen kann: Bessere Grafik und mehr Freiheit - z.B. auch Spielermods. So gab es für den Rhythmus-Hit Beat Saber bisher nur auf dem PC zusätzliche Levels aus Fan-Kreationen, was auf der Konsole nicht möglich war.6. Tonausgabe:Für mich der letzte und kürzeste Punkt. Kurzum: Die Tonausgabe ist ein klarer Schwachpunkt der Rift. Klassische Kopfhörer sind nicht vorhanden, stattdessen versteckte Lautsprecher im Haltering. Diesen fehlt es klar an Bass und sie klingen recht blechern. Persönlich bin ich sowieso kein besonderer Fan von Kopfhörern in VR, da ich es nicht mag, komplett abgeschottet von der Aussenwelt zu sein, auch wenn das natürlich der Illusion abträglich ist. Ich benutze dennoch lieber mein 2.1 System.Trotzdem: Ein klarer Schwachpunkt der Rift S. Hoffentlich finden sich bald gute Drittanbieter-Lösungen, denn trotz eines 3.5mm Klinke-Anschlusses passt nicht jedes Headset auch zu dem Haltesystem der Rift S. In-Ear Kopfhörer sind natürlich auch eine Lösung. Wen dieser Punkt besonders stört, sollte meine Bewertung eher als 4 Sterne ansehen.
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on 22 May 2019
review_title: Rift S: Gutes Einsteigergerät - leider mit Datenkrake Facebook im Gepäck

one_reviews_text: * Edited 2020-Sep-05 *As of Oct 1, 2020 a Facebook account will be required to use this hardware.  Existing users have until Jan1, 2023 to covert to Facebook or the bulk of features will not be available and titles may not work at all.  AVOID this hardware and company and go with a Vive or other VR option.  I for one, will not continue to use this product.  It’s a plain and simple spyware campaign that Facebook continues to expand and is now trying to force upon all users of the Oculus line.  As a long time Oculus user, I find this repulsive and will not support this type of corporate behavior.  Rating reduced to one star because zero stars are not possible...* Edited 2019-Jun-02 - marked by ** - **I've used Oculus headsets since the first beta before Facebook owned it.  This headset promises to be the first step in making VR accessible to the PC masses.  It uses a single connection, no external sensors, and is plug and play (in theory).The graphics are a slight step up from the last iteration, noticeable, but not massive.  The controllers are likewise a slight step up from the previous generation and very easy to adapt to.The new see through cameras and guardian system works very well.  If you are new to Oculus, this is a visual barrier to let you know when you are going to run into things in the 'real world'.  With the headset on, you see a camera view of the real world.  You trace out your play area with a 'laser' and this defines your play space, surrounded by virtual walls.  The setup is easy and intuitive.Responsiveness is great and much better than single or dual sensor tracking of old.  There is no break in the motion when a sensor loses sight of the headset because this headset tracks from the inside out using cameras placed all around the headset.Also gone is the glare from the lenses.  Bright scenes had no glare around the edges (halo) like the last set.  Colors were good and vibrant.  **In dark scenes the LCD panel shows its weakness with washed out blacks (more like grey than black).  In dark scenes it is very hard to distinguish items due to a lack of contrast.  When playing Arizona Sunshine as a test, I knew the area and still couldn't see things in the dark with a flashlight.  Unlike the last panel, this severe lack of contrast and black level is a strong drawback from OLED panels for space sims (Elite Dangerous, etc.) or shooters i where there will be a lot of dark areas.**** The lenses don't steam up as fast as the old units although I do notice that my face is much more 'sealed' to the front of the unit.  This is good and bad (for me).  It is good in that it seals out light almost entirely.  However, I used to cheat and look through the gaps by my nose to see the keyboard, etc., in the past.  Now I have to physically lift the unit to find the keyboard, etc.  It should be noted that I use my Oculus more for seated gaming (Elite, Project Cars, Assetto Corsa, etc.) than standing games.  When playing standing games with the touch controllers the better seal would be preferred.  If you want to peek into the 'real world' you can double tap the Oculus button on the touch controller to enable the cameras.  This works well, and is thoughtful, for situations when you are spinning around shooting zombies and become entangled in your headset cord. **** The built in sound is very weak with no bass.  A canon shot sounds like a 'tink' rather than a 'boom' in War Thunder for example.  The headset uses directional sound from the strap to direct sound down towards your ears.  Unlike the last version, headphones will not fit over the straps on this version.  While it does include a built in microphone, I prefer using a noise canceling headset for gaming that also provides a richer sound (for seated play).  This design simply does not allow for that.  The sponge on the strap sides (used for comfort) create a 3/4-1" (20-25 mm) offset, on each side, that hold the headphone arms (and ear pads) away from your head.  This applies to over the ear, or on ear headphones.  If you use ear buds it won't be a problem.**Speaking of the strap, it works surprisingly well with a single wheel to tighten the unit to your head.  It pulls the headset to your face and there is a release to move the actual lens part (the big box) away from your face.  If you wear glasses, this is far better than the last set.  It is a little harder to get the up-down into focus because the 'box' does not pivot in any way.  All in all, it's a mix of good and bad over the old unit.  Definitely easier to put on, although it goes back to full tight every time it's removed, but harder to get into the sweet spot for focus.  Once in focus, it stays put very well** Note - I raised the rating by 2 stars after getting a replacement and further testing. **So why one star?  Because it doesn't work.  Upon first plugging it in, you will have to update the BIOS on everything (headset and controllers).  Then you go through the VR setup.  First problem was a black screen when instructed to continue the setup in VR.  I unplugged it from one display port and plugged it into another and it started working.  I finished setup and jumped into a game.  After less than 5 minutes in the game, the screen goes black again.  It was still on because I could see the backlight, but no picture and no sound from Oculus home.  I can hear system sounds coming from the headset though.  A reboot later and it's still not working.  Unplug, and re-plug into a new ports and it's still dead as a door knob.  So much for quality control.  The Oculus app shows all green check boxes next to the device, as though all is good when it is definitely not.** I received a replacement from Amazon for another go at this model.  The replacement also crashed during setup, but afterwards has worked so far.  It appears the first one may have had a defective board that once heated, failed.  I am rating this as 3 stars because the increased resolution and reduction in the 'screen door' effect does not overcome the issue with the lack of rich blacks and contrast.  The old panel was better in that regard.  Also the change to the strap, while comfortable, completely negates using superior headsets.  Sound is every bit as important to immersion as the visual elements.  In this regard, the sound in this headset is a big leap backwards.  Convenient yes, but practical no.Performance wise, I have had a chance to run it through some benchmarks.  This headset operates at 80 frames per second (ideally) as opposed to 90 FPS on the last Rift.  On the surface this appears to be worse, but in practice it is not noticeable and did not lead to discomfort at all.  I also noticed that this headset was able to keep up at a full 80 FPS in games that previously would drop to ASW (45 FPS).  ASW is the Oculus method of dynamically creating filling frames when the frame rate drops below ideal.  This helps with discomfort and creates a smoother playback image even through the frame rate is less than the desired 90.  This headset did not drop below 80 in most of my tests using the same settings as the previous unit that would have stayed in ASW with the same settings.  Clearly the unit is better at aiding graphics cards in rendering frames quicker.**I am running a current game rig with an Intel 8700k and an NVidia 1080ti.  Pretty standard fair and one that worked reliably with the old headset.  For $400 and after waiting years for an update, I had hoped that the headsets are intended to last longer than 10 minutes.  I feel like I'm beta testing the original again.  It's clear to me they have a number of kinks to work out.  This one is going back immediately.** After spending some time reviewing the latest drivers, etc., it still seems like an early release, but one that is worthy of $399.The alternative I would consider is the new Vive Index.  However, the Vive is MUCH more expensive at $1,000.  Furthermore, it still requires satellites setup around the room and can suffer from interruptions as a result (it usually works well in practice).  This makes it less portable and more of a pain to switch between seated play and standing play in many situations.  Also the touted 144 FPS refresh rate is highly unlikely in anything but simple whack-a-mole type games (Beat Saber, etc.).  You will need significant hardware (2080, etc.) to push that frame rate.  The controllers on the Vive also seem better (how it is held, finder tracking, etc.), but it isn't yet fully implemented and there are a lot of questions around play with legacy device support.For these reasons, the Oculus seems like the better consumer deal.If you will be playing mostly things like Arizona Sunshine, Beat Saber, etc., this is really a very easy headset to use, and is much easier to setup and put away too. **
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 21 May 2019
review_title: Not ready for release and now Facebook is required (2020-09-01)

one_reviews_text: Si andas buscando unas buenas gafas de VR y tu presupuesto es de 450€ (o algo menos en Black Friday) y no quieres seguir leyendo te diré pares aquí, que éstas son las gafas de realidad virtual que andas buscando. Si quieres saber por qué te lo explico a continuación.La definición de la pantalla es un avance con respecto al modelo anterior y está eones por delante de mi viejo Oculus DK2.El Sde, o el efecto rejilla que hay entre los píxeles, pues prácticamente desaparece. Existe, pero te tienes que fijar a propósito para encontrarlo.Pasamos al sweet spot o punto dulce. Esto quiere decir el porcentaje de lente que queda enfocada una vez que te ajustas las gafas... Una pasada, con mi IPD (distancia de pupila a pupila) de unos 63 queda toda la pantalla clara y legible. Me parece un avance brutal en la experiencia. En el mercado no existe NINGÚN visor de este precio ni de precio más elevado que tenga esta calidad de lentes.El tracking de los mandos y del casco es espectacular, especialmente después de las últimas actualizaciones de firmware. Viniendo de un DK2 y posteriormente haber peleado con WMR durante más de un año, qué queréis que os diga. Me parece buenísimo. Sólo escondiendo las manos a conciencia durante un buen rato se pueden perder del seguimiento, pero es que cuando vuelven a estar en cámara la recuperación es instantánea. La cabeza no tiene problemas de seguimiento de ningún tipo, pero algunas personas dicen que debes conectarlo en un USB bien alimentado si quieres evitar problemas. En esta versión se cambian las dos cámaras externas del modelo anterior por cinco cámaras que van metidas en el propio casco. Tenemos experiencia en 360 grados desde el inicio de la compra. En el modelo anterior, el CV1, había que adquirir una cámara extra para obtener la misma experiencia.Sobre el FOV (field of view) o campo de visión, pues tiene el que hay en todas las gafas actuales menos Pimax, esto es 110 grados en diagonal. Es cierto que hacia los extremos en horizontal da la sensación de que acaban un poquito de forma abrupta dando un poco la impresión de gafas de bucear, pero nada que arruine la expereriencia. Por contra tienen bastante campo de visión en vertical. Hay cascos bastante más caros que solucionan esto hoy en día, por ejemplo las Pimax, pero como digo, son mucho más caras y necesitas un equipo de la NASA para que los juegos corran medio bien porque también tienen más resolución.Sonido: si las quieres enseñar a tus amigos y poner experiencias tipo Google Earth y tal, pues no tendrás problemas. Si quieres inmersión y buenos bajos, pues vas a necesitar buscar unos auriculares aparte, quizás es lo más negativo, pero no llega a ser determinante y hay formas de adaptar cascos buenos a este kit de VR.El ecosistema de Oculus es el mejor, no creo que haya que hablar demasiado sobre esto ni sobre sus juegos exclusivos. Esto pone a las Rift S por delante de cualquier competencia de entrada y casi de forma definitiva.El refresco de la pantalla es de 80hz. A priori peor que los 90hz del modelo anterior, pero al ser un LCD sí que he notado mucha fluidez con mi GTX 970. Éstos 10hz menos disminuyen en un 11% la potencia necesaria de la tarjeta gráfica, o sea, es como si tu gráfica fuera un 11% más potente y por tanto menos saltos de imagen y más sensación de fluidez. Además, de la pantalla hay que destacar que tiene unos colores vibrantes y que con el panel LCD no queda ni rastro del ghosting o estela habitual en los paneles OLED.En lo referente a comodidad, creo son muy cómodas, aunque quizás la esponja pueda dar algo de calor.Recomendaría la compra? Si no te piensas gastar más de 1000€ en unas gafas de VR y quieres un producto que está por delante de cualquier cosa que exista en el mismo rango de precio, sí, éstas son las tuyas. Además irán bastante bien en equipos con requisitos de entrada para VR, lo que te ahorrará tener que comprar una RTX 2080 y un equipo nuevo para poder jugar a saltos, como ocurre con los visores que ofrecen más resolución y mayor tasa de refresco pero no necesariamente una mejor expereriencia.Si no te quieres gastar 450€ espera al black Friday, y además seguro que bajan de precio oficial en uno o dos años. Si eres un apretado y quieres disfrutar de la VR como un enano, cómpralas ya!Mi veredicto serían 4,5 estrellas en total, están muy bien y estoy muy contento con las mías pero no son perfecas, eso hay que tenerlo en cuenta. Ahora, teniendo en cuenta el precio, sí que se merece las 5 estrellas.Un saludo si has llegado hasta aquí.
review_date: Reviewed in Spain on 2 June 2019
review_title: La mejor VR por su precio con diferencia

one_reviews_text: I did alot of research before I took the plunge on this, being that I already have a CV1. Would it be worth the upgrade?My main doubts before upgrading were,1. Will my IPD be OK?Mine sits at 61mm and after setting the software to match I have had no issues here, everything is crystal clear and no eye strain. Ideally you want to be at 63.5mm but 2-3mm either side of this and I don't think you will have a problem. However this is subjective to the individual.2. The black levels, being this is an LCD panel and not OLED.Omg the black levels are amazing! I was very surprised just how good ALL the colours are, definitely on Par with the CV1, maybe slightly better!3. Tracking, coming from outside in to inside out.This is better than what my 2 sensor set up was. Again if you put your hands behind your back you'll loose tracking but this was always the case for me. Unfortunately when you draw say a bow, you will loose tracking if you put the controller too close to your face but you can adapt to this. I feel overall the tracking is better than 2 sensors but not if you have 3.4. God rays and screen door effect? Without a doubt a thing of the past!5. Resolution is only a small bump up on paper but WOW the LCD panels pixel density is far better which is also why the screen door has all but vanished. Text is VASTLY sharper!6. Sound quality.The sound quality is actually surprisingly good but it's not quite got the base of the CV1 headphones, but still good overall.  You can still plug in a 3rd party solution via the headphone jack.7.Comfort.The CV1 was very comfortable I found but again so is this, it's just different and takes a bit of getting use to the halo design. It's also actually nice NOT having ear phones pressed against your ears.8.Value for money.This is where I feel this really shines. When you compare it to the price of the Valve index, touching close to £1000 for the full setup or the HP Reverb at the £500-£600 region. I feel this Headset hits the sweet spot for being both good value for money and a good all rounder in the specs department.9.Lastly Software.I've always loved the Oculus software, very polished and easy to use especially when you compare to Windows MR. The new pass through cameras are great for having a peek into the real world. When you step out of your Guardian boundaries this kicks in.UPDATE... I'm getting alot of tracking issues where the tracking stops working completely! Also I'm getting an intermittent black screen usually on first boot of the PC. You can fix this by replugging in the USB but it's not ideal. Also I've noticed an intermittent flash of static, if you blink you can almost miss it but this occurs at least every 5-10 mins.I hope this all gets fixed with future updates. Unfortunately the way I see it this should have all been working properly from day one as I never had problems with the DK2 or CV1.I have returned it for a refund. I'm sure one day they will sort these issues via a firmware patch. When they do this will be a good buy which is why I've given it 3 stars and not 1. Originally with my first impressions after an hour of use I gave this 5 stars with my review. But now after 12 hours of play I have started to notice more issues.UPDATE!! As of now September 2019 with recent updates the Rift S is now fixed of all its issues that I mentioned.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 31 May 2019

one_reviews_text: I pre-ordered my Oculus Rift S. It arrived, as promised, on the release day, and I was very excited to get it up and running. Even though I already knew my PC was above the requirements of the Oculus Rift S I started by running the system compatibility check.  It passed with all green check marks.  Next I ensured my PC and all of its drivers were up-to-date, and proceeded to install the Oculus App on my PC.The install went smoothly, and the next step was to plug-in and setup the Rift S device.  This also went very smoothly, and I was up and running in my new VR world with no hiccups. That was until all of a sudden the headset quit tracking the controllers properly, and in VR my hands were showing as if they were crisscrossed across my face (this was about 10 minutes into the experience). I took the headset off and decided to restart the software.  Upon restarting, I clicked on my devices and noticed that it said the Rift S was active, connected to the display port, but that it needed to be connected to a USB 3.0 port (which it was).  I followed all available troubleshooting... tried different USB ports, tried updating drivers again, re-installing the software, etc. etc. with still no luck. After 5 hours of trying to get it to work again with no avail I figured I submitted a support ticket to Oculus and figured I'd try again the next day.The next morning I contacted support through Oculus' chat feature on their website. The representative I got was very friendly, offered great communication, and made a true effort to get the issue resolved for me. She provided further troubleshooting instructions (un-installing the software in safe-mode and removing all Oculus files/folders from the system, and trying to re-install the software).  She advised me respond to the email if that did not work, and that I could also contact the support chat at any time for further help.  Unfortunately her troubleshooting instructions did not work, and I was left to wait in queue for two hours to chat with another support representative that evening.  The representative I got was of absolutely NO help, did not offer any further solutions or troubleshooting suggestions, and told me all I could do was wait until they figured it out.  I was very disappointed with this customer support service which contributes to the one star rating.To confirm, the headset itself still had audio (you could hear a background tune through the headset, and there were three dots in a white rectangle on the screen of the VR headset, but that is all it would do after I encountered the issue.  Also a side note, the USB plug of the device was getting EXTREMELY hot.Needless to say, for the price of the unit, I did not want to have it sitting on my desk as a nearly $600 paper weight, waiting for a resolution.  I have spent over 12 hours troubleshooting, and doing everything/anything I can to try and get the device to work with no success.  I am returning the device, and will be considering another product to get back into the VR world.  The 10 minutes of use I DID get with the unit left me hungry for more... so hopefully I'll have better luck with a different brand/product, as there seems to continuously be more and more options out there.I would strongly suggest either considering a different option if you are looking for a VR device, or waiting until Oculus has their suff figured out so they can offer a functioning product. I get it... its a new device and there are bound to be some glitches, but the lack of support, and the fact that there are MANY others with the exact same issue I'm experiencing
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on 23 May 2019
review_title: I would suggest looking at other VR options or waiting.

one_reviews_text: Questa è una mia piccola recensione, non sarà professionale ma spero apprezziate.Iniziamo:La risoluzione di 1,280 x 1,440 per occhio  (2,560 x 1,440 totale) si fa sentire, al confronto con il vecchio Rift, questo è proprio un bel passo avanti. La qualità dell'immagine è migliorata notevolmente, vi assicuro che rimarrete molto sorpresi.Per quanto riguarda gli HZ, in questo caso ce ne sono 80 al confronto con i 90 del precedente e credetemi, non si nota assolutamente la differenza..(in più era uscita una voce di un possibile Hz OverClock).Ottiche completamente nuove e migliorate, un esempio molto banale per testare le nuove lenti, sono le letture.Quando andrete a leggere qualsiasi cosa, ora non vedrete più sfocato ma vedrete tutto a meraviglia. (ve ne accorgerete meglio con il visore di persona che leggendo questa "recensione") Stessa cosa anche per le lunghe distanze, dove prima si vedeva leggermente sfocato, ora si potrà vedere meglio anche in lontananza.Al contrario del vecchio Rift, per regolare le lenti, ci dobbiamo affidare al software e non al "bottone" sotto al visore come in precedenza ma state tranquilli, si regolano bene anche cosi.Il Tracking.Che dire sul tracking? Beh, con le sue 5 telecamere, Il Rift S permette di essere utilizzato senza sensori!Quindi, ora possiamo girare liberamente senza preoccuparci di non eseguire per bene un 360°. Per ora non ho riscontrato nessun punto negativo, un esempio sono i giochi in cui devi usare arco e frecce oppure tirar fuori una spada da dietro la schiena. Qualche recensione negativa parlava di problemi di tracking quando appunto si doveva tirare con l'arco oppure prendere spada e scudo da dietro le spalle.. Beh, problema assolutamente non riscontrato! Per quanto mi riguarda funziona tutto a meraviglia.Tuttavia, ci sono alcuni punti dove le telecamere non fanno funzionare bene il tracking dei controller, i cosi detti "punti morti" ma con qualche movimento adeguato e poca pratica la cosa si risolve!Pass Throught. Tecnologia nuova per Rift S ed effettivamente è davvero utile! Oltre a usarla per creare il vostro "spazio vr" questa tecnologia si può usare ogni volta che si vuole, magari per controllare che tutto sia apposto, prendere il telefono, controllare il pc ecc.. Si può attivare premendo due volte il tasto Oculus sul controller destro, questa opzione si può attivare nelle impostazioni del programma oculus.Uno dei contro ma tranquillamente rimediabile di questo visore è l'audio.. Questo nuovo Oculus non ha cuffie ma un audio integrato che non fa schifo eh sia chiaro, anzi è "abbastanza comodo" ma ovviamente essendo un audio integrato, non potrete godervi a pieno l'esperienza in Vr.Il problema delle cuffie con ben sapete tutti, si può risolvere molto velocemente, perchè il Rift S ha un jack per le cuffie proprio sul visore, quindi potrete montare direttamente le vostre cuffie del pc. Non si esclude qualche strano prototipo di cuffia da abbinare al Rift S. Anzi, qualcosa online già si trova se non erro ;)Altre informazioni sono il cavo, più lungo di un metro rispetto al Rift precedente.
review_date: Reviewed in Italy on 26 May 2019

one_reviews_text: Coming from the original rift I can tell the rift s has far sharper image quality, the lenses are a huge improvement with a much bigger sweet spot and cause less distortion and warping in the VR world as you move your head from side to side. The headset was a breeze to set up and so far the tracking seems to work flawlessly, very happy!Update: Any one experiencing the screen going blank after a while or strange random flashes of static from time to time will want to make sure they not only disable USB power down in windows but also in steam VR which can be found in the developer section, once I did this the headset has been running flawlessly.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 23 May 2019

one_reviews_text: Ho acquistato un anno fa Oculus Rift classico, e da un mesetto sono un felice possessore del Rift S.Dividerò questa recensione in due parti distinte: una prima parte per chi non ha mai avuto un visore per la realtà virtuale, e una seconda parte per chi già possiede il Rift classico e si sta domandando se vale la pena passare al Rift S.PER CHI NON HA UN VISORE:Avete un pc che abbia le caratteristiche raccomandate per l'oculus? Avete 450 euro che volete spendere per videogiocare in un modo totalmente nuovo? Bene. Acquistate l'Oculus Rift.E la recensione potrebbe tranquillamente fermarsi qui, perchè finchè non lo proverete coi vostri occhi non potrete capire il livello di immersione, coinvolgimento e divertimento che questa periferica potrà regalarvi.Tutte le persone a cui l'ho fatto provare (me compreso) rimangono a bocca aperta la prima volta ed è davvero difficile cercare di spiegare a parole la sensazione che l'oculus genera.In questa parte di recensione vorrei infatti semplicemente rispondere ad alcune domande che io mi sono fatto prima di acquistarlo e che magari ora vi state facendo anche voi:- il tracking com'è?Molto buono. Mi spaventava l'assenza dei sensori esterni ma devo dire che il tracking non dà nessun tipo di problema.- e la risoluzione dell'immagine?2560×1440 pixel, maggiore rispetto al vecchio Oculus.- giochi ce ne sono?Tantissimi. Moltissime esperienze brevi per testarlo e farlo testare ad amici e famiglia, e molti giochi completi. La maggior parte di questi ultimi nasce per essere usata esclusivamente con visori e garantiscono un'esperienza veramente diversa da qualsiasi altra cosa a cui eravate abituati.- è difficile da usare?No. Ha imparato ad usarlo mia nonna di 85 anni e si è divertita come una matta.- dopo un po' stufa?A un mese dall'acquisto lo uso ancora quotidianamente. (E usavo il vecchio Oculus ancora moltissimo a un anno dall'acquisto)- fa venire nausea/mal di testa/morte istantanea?Molto soggettivo. A me solo pochissimi titoli fanno venire un po' di nausea, ma normalmente lo uso anche per più di un'ora consecutiva senza alcun problema.- ma oltre a giocarci ci si può fare altro?Sì. Gli ambiti applicativi sono davvero tantissimi. Oltre a videogiocare potrete: usare maps VR per scoprire posti in 3d in giro per il mondo e visitarli, disegnare in 3d con alcune delle app di grafica, vedere qualsiasi film come se foste in un cinema (BigScreen), vedere film in 3d come se ci foste dentro, imparare qualcosa di nuovo tramite le numerose app di divulgazione scientifica e non (Body VR ad esempio), conoscere gente nuova attraverso le app social (e giocarci assieme) e potrei continuare.- quanto sono lunghi i vari cavi? Ho bisogno di extender/prolunghe?Finalmente il cavo del visore è di una lunghezza sufficiente. Col vecchio Oculus ci si sentiva sempre un po' legati vista la (breve) lunghezza del cavo.- quanto spazio devo avere per potermi muovere e giocare decentemente?Io ho creato uno spazio di circa 3 metri x 2 metri ed è perfetto. Si riesce comunque a giocare anche con meno spazio, tipo 2 metri x 1.5 metri.- che scheda video devo avere? Processore?Io uso una RTX 2070 e viaggio senza problemi. L'ho comunque provato con una gtx 970 e tutti i giochi andavano comunque lisci come l'olio (abbassando ovviamente le impostazioni grafiche). Fate attenzione al processore, io avevo un i5 6600k a 4.5 ghz e girava spesso tra l'80% e il 90% di utilizzo, adesso con un 9700k non ho più nessun tipo di problema.In conclusione, come ho scritto all'inizio, è difficile spiegarvi PERCHE' dovreste comprarlo, ma fidatevi, se ne avete la possibilità è davvero un'esperienza unica nel suo genere, e questo è il primo passo per il futuro del videogioco.PER CHI GIA' POSSIEDE LA VECCHIA VERSIONE:Voglio farvela breve: se riuscite a rivendere il Rift classico e a comprarvi il Rift S per circa la metà del prezzo ha assolutamente senso l'upgrade. Altrimenti io ci penserei un attimo prima di fare il passaggio al nuovo visore.450€ per un'esperienza che avete già con l'Oculus classico NON sono soldi ben spesi. La differenza non è tale da giustificare la spesa. Viceversa, se riusciste a vendere il vecchio visore e dovreste investire magari la metà, beh, a questo punto le cose cambiano.Infatti il nuovo Rift S è migliore in tutto rispetto al predecessore.La differenza di risoluzione si nota immediatamente, soprattutto in giochi dove sono presenti scritte o piccoli elementi a schermo. Mentre fortunatamente la differenza di refresh dello schermo (che si abbassa dai 90hz del vecchio Rift agli 80hz del nuovo) non si avverte minimamente. Il nuovo schermo LCD non fa rimpiangere il vecchio OLED: adesso le scritte bianche su sfondo nero sono definite e nitide, e non circondate da aloni come sul vecchio Rift.E' inoltre più comodo, si infila e sfila molto più facilmente.E' più leggero, o per lo meno il peso è distribuito in maniera migliore, e affatica molto meno la testa rispetto al predecessore.Il tracking è ottimo, le recensioni che dicono il contrario probabilmente si riferiscono alla primissima versione uscita che aveva un firmware un po' instabile.L'audio, nonostante l'assenza di cuffie, è molto buono. Ricordatevi però che anche chi vi sta attorno sente quelle che sentite voi...Concludendo, ripeto che il Rift S è migliore in tutto rispetto al vecchio Rift ma ovviamente, per chi possiede già un Oculus non sarà presente l'effetto WOW della prima volta.Rift S è comunque un ulteriore passo avanti nel mondo della realtà virtuale, sta a voi decidere se vale la pena farlo.
review_date: Reviewed in Italy on 2 August 2019
review_title: Importante passo avanti rispetto a Rift classico

one_reviews_text: after getting the Oculus on release day i was soo hyped but then u realise what a Frustrating pile of rubbish it really is, not even  ready for a release i cant even play a game for at least 10mins without the Screen going black, And constant computer Restarts just to let it do the same black screen over and over with soo many other ppl with the same complaints on the Oculus forums, The customer service is a complete joke waste of time, Theres a fix  but it requires unplugging cables in and out every time the screen goes black no thanks ill take my money elsewere!!!!!
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 24 May 2019

one_reviews_text: The Oculus Rift uses one USB and one HDMI cable, however the Oculus Rift S uses one USB and one displayport cable. So my "Oculus ready" laptop can't use the oculus I just spent over $400 on until I hopefully find a way I can get a third party adapter to plug into the type-C since HDMI adapters allegedly don't work for it. If you're thinking of getting this for your laptop, unless you have a displayport or mini-displayport, DO NOT GET THE OCULUS RIFT SUpdate: Got a displayport to USB-C because I found that could potentially work, since displayport to HDMI doesn't. Unfortunately that didn't help and I still am unable to use this $400 sleeping mask for anything else. I reiterate, do not buy this junk
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 May 2019

one_reviews_text: Llevo varios días probándolas en profundidad y estoy muy contento con las gafas. Tienen varios puntos que se podrían mejorar pero en mi opinión es de lo mejor que hay en el mercado ahora mismo en relación calidad precio. Mi lista de pros y contras:PROS:- El sistema de sujeción a la cabeza de Lenovo (el mismo que usa play station vr) es comodísimo y se adapta bien a todos los tamaños y formas.- Ya no es necesario tener toda la habitación cableada y llena de sensores. Ahora el tracking se hace "inside-out", es decir que las cámaras de las gafas te posicionan en la habitación y te hacen el seguimiento de los mandos.- El sistema Passthrough es una maravilla que te evita tener que quitarte las gafas y te ayuda a "recolocarte" en la habitación cuando te has desorientado. Básicamente si aprietas dos veces un botón o te sales fuera de la zona delimitada se ponen en funcionamiento las camaras delanteras y ves la habitación en blanco y negro.- Mandos muy cómodos e intuitivos. La pila dura bastante y parecen resistentes a los golpes.- En algunos sentidos ha habido una mejora en las lentes, ahora funcionan con LCD en vez de OLED lo que ofrece mejor resolución, menos "glare" y "efecto puerta"- Los altavoces integrados se oyen bien y te evitan tener que colocarte auriculares/cascos cada vez que te pones las gafas. De todas formas dispones de una entrada jack por si quieres usar tus propios auriculares.CONTRAS:- Las almohadillas deberían ser de cuero/plástico lavable y no de espuma. Cuando llevas un rato jugando se empapan de sudor y aunque son desmontables no parece fácil de lavar. Supongo que en futuro irán sacando accesorios, yo lo veo como algo imprescindible por higiene.- El cable es un poco corto, no es nada que no se puede arreglar con un alargador pero por el precio que tienen ya podrían haber incluído un par de metros mas...- No entiendo cómo no vienen con algún sistema de ventilación como hacen con las gafas de fpv de los drones. Por ejemplo las fatshark tienen un ventilador que puedes conectar o desconectar y te desempaña las gafas. Esto tampoco es un problema específico de estas gafas ya que ninguna lo tiene pero es algo molesto que deberían solucionar.- Los mandos deberían venir con algún tipo de sistema de recarga de batería y no solo con pilas. Además la tapa viene sujeta con imán y en ciertas ocasiones se desliza y se abre. No es nada grave pero sí es incómodo.- A pesar de los pros de usar LCD en vez de OLED que comentaba anteriormente los LCD tienen el problema de que los colores se ven menos vivos y los negros menos negros.
review_date: Reviewed in Spain on 2 June 2019

one_reviews_text: - N'achete pas l'oculus rift S !- Pourquoi ?- Ah ba si tu achètes ce produit et que tu as la conf* qui va avec tu risque de te dé-sociabiliser à mort !- Pourquoi ?- PAR CE QUE C'EST LE MEILLEUR TRUC QUI PUISSE EXISTER POUR UN MORDUE DE TECH ET DE J.V !- Ah donc je l'achète ?- Evidemment !Plus sérieusement c'est un super produit, mon entourage pas hyper fan des jeux vidéo, par exemple ma sœur est littéralement rester avec le casque 3 bonne heures sans même s'en rendre compte et sa qu'on fasse beaucoup de jeux vidéo ou non le temps passe assez vite en VR. On en prendrais presque même la notion faire attention a sa d’ailleurs.Sinon avec la config qui va bien c'est du bonheur pas mal de petit jeu/Demo gratuite pour bien découvrir l’environnement VR.Je vous conseille également d'acheter le jeu beat saber, vous verrez il fera un carton !Il est possible de réellement faire du sport avec. (Pas comme la wii a l'époque ou on faisait juste bouger le main et sa passer) La il faudra y mettre du sien.Pour ce qui ne connaisse pas du tout et qui se disent moi j'ai pas beaucoup de place dans ma chambre/bureau ...Pour pas mal de jeux une petite surface suffis largement.Configuration de mon pc :Processeur : Intel - i7 7700K(7eme génération) Cadencé à 4.20 GHzCarte mère :  AsusTek - PRIME Z270-PCarte graphique : Asus Strix - GTX 1060 6GBMémoire : Corsair - Dominator de 8 GoX2  (16GO)Disque : SSD : Crucial - de 489.05 Go | HDD :  TOSHIBA - de 931.51 GoLe logiciel Oculus (8Go) et les jeux sont sur le SSD je pense que c'est mieux mais je n'ai pas tester sur le HDD.Ps: Excusez-moi pour les fautes.
review_date: Reviewed in France on 11 August 2019
review_title: N'achetez pas ceci si vous compter avoir une vie !!!!!!!!!!!!!

one_reviews_text: Having bought the Rift S due to my old one's speakers packing up just as the S was announced I just decided to upgrade to this, Unfortunately it's not really an upgrade. Materials are cheaper feeling The audio is sub-par and the tracking is woefully off compared to the original, I think I'm going to send this back and order a replacement speaker as to be honest this just isn't a good upgrade and if you have the original i'd seriously reconsider before dropping cash on this.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 26 May 2019
review_title: A downgrade for original Rift owners

one_reviews_text: Zunächst einmal muss man sagen, dass die Installation eine Katastrophe ist. Die Occulus Software ist ganze 7 GB groß und wird nicht mitgeliefert sondern muss aus dem Internet geladen. Selbst mit einer SSD braucht nach dem Download die Installation eine ganze Weile (trotz high end PC: Intel Core 7 8700K, 32GB Ram, GTX 2080). Dann folgt ein Firmware Update, das ebenfalls lange dauert.Danach lief aber immer noch nichts, weil die Software die Brille zwar erkannte, aber danach ständig neustartete.Alles mögliche aktualisiert etc., nichts half. Also Occulus Software Reparatur Funktion verwendet, was zur Folge hatte, dass wieder 7GB geladen wurden. Dann lief es endlich.Bin trotzdem verärgert, weil das Ganze viel Zeit gekostet hat.Besonders erfreulich: Die Brille kann auch nur verwendet werden, wenn man sich vorher bei Occulus registriert. Da ich mich nicht mit Facebook anmelden wollte, musste ich einen neuen Account anlegen, welcher eine Bestätigung per Mail erforderte. Leider kam die Bestätigungsmail erst nach einigen Stunden.EDIT: Mittlerweile läut die Software runder und auch die Occulus Download Server funktionieren schneller.Witziger Sideface, warum ich am Anfang wohl so massive Probleme hatte: Die Oculus Software kommt (oder kam in der Vergangenheit) nicht klar damit, wenn im Installationspfad Umlaute sind, d.h. man einen Windows User Account mit Umlauten/Sonderzeichen verwendet. Das Problem konnte ich zum Glück selbst lösen, indem ich die Oculus Debug Console geöffnet habe. Ich habe es zwar auch mit dem Oculus Support versucht, der hat mir allerdings erst nach 7 Tagen geantwortet ohne Lösungsvorschlag.Nach einigen Monaten Benutzung kann ich einen Stern mehr vergeben, weil die Idee und die Brille grundsätzlich gut sind, wenn denn mal alles funktioniert. Leider ist oftmals nicht der Fall. Viele der Apps in der Oculus Bibliothek funktionieren nicht einwandfrei mit der Rift S und wurden nicht ausreichend angepasst. Das resultiert, z.T. in fehlenden Sound, fehlende  oder fehlerhafte Steuerung. Wie zuvor erwähnt ist auch der Oculus Support echt nicht besonders schnell.Die Brille ist m.E. grundsätzlich durchaus nicht schlecht und in Sachen Bildqualität eine deutliche Verbesserungen zur normalen Rift, auch den Sound (wenn er funktioniert) ist besser als sein Ruf. Das Tracking funktioniert meistens relativ fehlerfrei. Leider leider kann und will ich die Brille nicht gesondert von der Software bewerten, da beides aus meiner Sicht miteinander verbunden ist und zusammengehört. Die beste Brille nutzt einem wenig, wenn man sie wegen schlechter Software nur unzureichend benutzen kann. Ich würde meine PS4 auch schlecht finden, wenn das Betriebssystem ständig bedingt, dass z.T. schwerwiegende Fehler entstehen und ich viele Spiele gar nicht vernünftig spielen kann.Letztendlich hat man mehr das Gefühl ein Beta-Tester zu sein, als alles andere....
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on 23 May 2019

one_reviews_text: My son wanted a VR headset for Christmas, an expensive but simple request.  Oh No.  Even though you have paid £400 for this product you cannot use it unless Facebook allows you to.  Once you have shelled out a a load of money before it will work you HAVE to have a Facebook account.  There is no other option!!  You have to pimp your child out to Facebook before you can use the item you have paid for.  My son has a life and friends in the real world, so until now had no need of a Facebook account.  So Christmas morning I had to set him up a Facebook account. You have to give Facebook your child's email address, mobile phone number and upload a photo of them (allegedly this will be deleted after sign up but who knows).  Facebook then suspends this new account for breach of there policies ( I don't know how I have not done anything with the account yet!!).  So he can't use his present!!.  To allow him to use the present I paid £400 for I had to let him use my Facebook account.  I know that Facebook is loved by Billions around the world, who like to post the fact that they have just made a sandwich.  I just feel that these things should be optional.  In short don't buy unless you and your child loves face book.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 25 December 2020
review_title: Don't buy unless you and your child loves Facebook

one_reviews_text: Ancien possesseur du Rift.Les bons points:- ASW2.0 fonctionne aussi avec le "S".-Le son est pas si pourri que ça.-Le screen door est diminué d'au moins d' 2x par rapport au S (vraiment ultra petit, à peine visible). On peut quasiment dire que y a plus de screen door.-La hausse de réso est pas dingue sur le papier mais combiné à la grille RGB, ça fait du bien.- Plus de station, moins de bordel. Installation ultra simplifiée.Du coup, on a une image plus clair/net, moins brouillonne, c'est vraiment notable.-Enfin un bien meilleur "sweet spot" vertical et les "halo" sont drastiquement réduit voir absent.Maintenant plus avoir les stations, c'est vraiment top mais je demande à voir plus dans la pratique car là, j'ai du souvent refaire le room scale (se fait en moins d 'une minute. Avec les cam ext, c'est  de venu très rapide). Aussi quelques écrans noirs, obligé donc de débrancher et rebrancher le casque. Apparemment, le problème est connu (patch à venir).EDIT (29/06/2019) : Pour les écrans noirs et le "roomscale", ça fait un moment que c'est plus le cas (depuis que j'ai fait la maj en beta 3 jours après la sortie).Par contre, il y a un problème récurent pour une grande majorité si ce n'est pas tous (sur tout les casques dans mon entourage sans exception), et même si les forums sont remplis de complaintes à ce sujet, le problème doit être plus médiatisé. Il y a un problème de "White Static Flashes", comme une perte de signal qui arrive dans de longue session. Et ce problème, à ce jour n'est pas fixé.Et comme beaucoup, j'attends que MR Oculus se bouge là dessus car sinon ( à défaut de renvoyer ce casque), je ne serai pas là pour le prochain.Voilà sinon le casque est top avec un super prix. Le système de fixation de chez Lonovo donne un meilleur confort.Pour ceux qui ont le CV1, ça vaut bien l'update avec la revente du Rift.
review_date: Reviewed in France on 6 June 2019

one_reviews_text: The overall 'clarity' of this headset is a definite improvement over the original Rift providing your eye's IPD falls near to 64.5mm and inside out tracking works quite well considering the added convenience. However unfortunately that's as far as the plus points go. If your IPD falls much outside side of 64.5mm, then it will be difficult to get a clear image at all times, the FOV may feel smaller than the original Rift and it will likely leave you feeling cross eyed and a bit dizzy.Unfortunately where the original Rift had a manual IPD adjuster that would slide the screens apart to match the distance between different people's eyes, this new Rift S has a fixed width and only 'software IPD adjustment' - which doesn't do anything to adjust the IPD of the lenses but rather instead ensure that the scale of the images is correct for whatever your IPD is. Ultimately this means that if you've not got a 64.5mm IPD you will never have it completely perfect (you'll be constantly trying to get it into a sweet spot of focus, it will be easy to have that then fall out of that focus point and if you're far from 64.5mm it may even cause you to feel dizzy or get a head ache. (People will tell you it's fine for whatever given IPD, but since all eyes are different, I can only talk about my own experiences where it was uncomfortable to use after a while). In my original Rift I can game for 4 hours + easily without any discomfort.Other negatives are the terrible audio quality (the built in speakers are very weak / give a tinny sound) and when I plugged in headphones into the 3.5mm headphone jack, I got a 'hiss' noise continually. What feels like pretty bad / cheap build quality compared to the original Rift. Worse black levels in dark scenes (in black scenes everything is just a shade of grey) due to the move from OLED to LED. Occasional flashes of white static, which to me felt like a fault with the device. A heavier cable that seems stiff and weighs you down compared to the original. Also personally I am also not a fan of the halo design, it felt heavy and bulky, although that may be down to preference as a lot of people prefer it.Overall, I've been a huge fan of Oculus / the Oculus Rift for years, I've had my original Rift for about 3 years and love it. I was totally excited to replace my original one with the new Rift S, but having used it - it's pretty much unusable for me (due to it giving me headaches / blurred vision), I've returned to my original Rift and have no issues again. I'll miss the potential for the better screen clarity, but it's not worth it for the discomfort.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 28 May 2019
review_title: Make sure your eyes are in the correct IPD range before you buy this headset!

one_reviews_text: 🧡  COSA MI HA COLPITO 🧡Sono passato dall'Oculus Rift a questo dopo circa 1 anno e mi è piaciuto così tanto che ne abbiamo preso un'altro per la mia compagna ed adesso ci divertiamo in partite Cooperative di vario genere.Le principali differenze con il vecchio modello sono diverse:-Una migliore Risoluzione ( al momento non la migliore in commercio ma senza dubbio superba nel suo rapporto qualità prezzo )-Un sistema di aggancio Halo Band ( in pratica avrete un fascione grande che avvolgerà la testa e con una manopola potretete stringerla, ed una fascia più piccola in alto che farà da fermo evitando di farlo scivolare verso il basso. La maschera del visore invece, tramite un bottone potrete portarla in avanti e indietro.- Peso e carico sulla nuca diminuito-Controller con fascia verso l'alto-Telecamere con le quali sarà possibile vedere la stanza dove ci troviamo ( in bianco e nero e leggermente distorta )ma sopratutto:-NESSUN SENSORE!!!Quest'ultimo punto è quello di maggiore interesse, poichè vi libera dalla prigionia di avere fili e sensori per tutta la casa. Ma funziona? Si, funziona molto bene e infinitamente bene rispetto al vecchio modello. Il tracking avviene in maniera precisa e veloce. Fare delle partite a Beat Saber senza Sensori credevo non fosse possibile ed invece è facilmente fattibile ma soprattutto molto divertente!Io avevo speso tanto tra prolunghe e un terzo sensore con il vecchio modello ma non era lontano da quello che ho potuto vedere con il Rift S, ed anzi devo dire che mi sembra ampiamente più fluido e maggiormente preciso nel tracking. Seppur ovviamente qualche volta fa i capricci ma con gli ultimi aggiornamenti sembra tutto filare liscio.Le batterie dei controller durano davvero tanto,  potrete farci dai 3 ai 5 giorni di gaming intenso con una carica completa 👍Adesso passiamo ad una visione generale. Questo visore ha bisogno di una presa Usb 3.0 e una porta Display Port da attaccare alla vostra scheda Video. Fare un PC decente per poter giocare non richiede una grossa cifra e anche con una scheda Video non molto potente riuscirete facilmente ad entrare nella realtà virtuale. Ma quali sono i suoi impieghi?-Gaming ( Davvero tantissima scelta. Vi consiglio lo store di Steam )-Educazione ( Anche qui abbiamo tanti titoli interessanti, dalla visione di Musei, Opere d'Arte a veri e propri Scenari che riproducono ambientazioni specifiche come ad esempio il Titanic )-Intrattenimento ( Se ne masticate di inglese avrete tanto da vedere, ci sarà anche l'opportunità con Big Screen Beta ad esempio di poter andare al Cinema a vedere un film in 3d come anche seguire dei corsi di Pittura )-Produttività ( Tante applicazioni che vi permetteranno multitasking con Desktop davvero giganti seduti comodamente nel vostro divano o degli incontri di Lavoro in Team dove ognuno può parlare e disegnare o mostrare qualche Idea, molto utile in sessioni di Brain Storming dove si cercano nuove idee da proporre)-Grafica 3d ( svariate applicazioni vi permetteranno di dipingere, creare oggetti 3d da soli o con l'aiuto di un Amico )Detto questo quando inserirete il vostro Visore vedrete un ambiente in grafica 3d con una profondità come quella della vostra vita reale, poter interagire con un mondo che non possiamo vedere ad occhio nudo è qualcosa da provare vi dimostrerà di come è facile ingannare la mente che risponderà agli stimoli come se si trovasse nel vostro mondo di tutti i giorni ( quindi vertigini, senso di libertà e di spazio, paura o gioia con scenari diversi, adrenalina e coordinazione negli sport, Stupore in ambienti impensabili etc...🙅‍♂ COSA NON MI HA CONVINTO 🙅‍♂Il sistema Audio è alquanto limitato, vi consiglio di utilizzare delle cuffie a parte. ( Le cuffie che vedete in foto sono delle KossKS75 che ho adattato seguendo una guida online, adesso il comparto Audio è comodo, fedele e con un buon volume Audio )Alcune volte il software fà i capricci e bisogna riavviare se non addirittura reinstallare il ClientL'interfaccia Oculus richiede un Account a Facebook per poter aggiungere amici, per fortuna c'è SteamLa Spugna nell'Holo Band assorbe facilmente il Sudore e non è possibile rimuoverla per LavarlaNessun Panno di Pulizia in Dotazione!!!!🌞 RACCOMANDAZIONI 🌝Se desiderate provare il VR non potrete trovare modello migliore. Al momento questo visore è il migliore sul mercato nel suo rapporto Qualità/Prezzo. La comodità di non avere sensori e cavi in tutta la casa permette anche una certa praticità ed eleganza. Se guardate altri modelli sappiate che dovrete spendere almeno il triplo per avere qualcosa di soddisfacente e che abbia senso rispetto a questo modello, come vi dicevo ad oggi la scelta cade sul Rift S.Tuffatevi in questo viaggio, non ve ne pentirete.Grazie per il tempo che ci avete dedicato 🤠🙋‍♀
review_date: Reviewed in Italy on 16 February 2020
review_title: Il RE dei Visori VR fino a i 1000 € 😊

one_reviews_text: Je me suis beaucoup documenté sur les différentes solutions proposées et j'ai choisi cet Oculus Rift S parce qu’il correspondait à mon cahier des charges minimum.... et je ne suis pas déçu.Je dispose déjà d'une config Tour PC Gamer musclée et mon système doit:- Etre assez puissant pour faire tourner sans trop de perte de qualité les jeux les plus réalistes proposés en VR ( exit pour moi l'oculus Quest).- Confortable: Pouvoir être mis avec des lunettes de vue ( pas de buée, bonne résolution, ergonomie des manettes, le moins de fils possibles.- Déplaçable facilement: passer du bureau au salon ou dans le jardin pour un maximum de degré de liberté. C'est très appréciable quand il y a des amis qui veulent essayer... donc exit pour moi les casques avec 2 ou 4 caméras extérieures.L'Oculus Rift m'a semblé le meilleur compromis. Puissant, pas de caméras extérieures à monter, un seul fil à la patte donnant 3m de débattement effectifs, son intégré (de bonne qualité, plus besoin d'écouteur ou casque audio) et l'effet WHAOU dès le début.Bien sûr, il y a la définition à améliorer et le sans fil total qui représenterait une avancée décisive, mais dans cette gamme raisonnable de prix (moins de 450€) le plaisir est là, immédiatement, qui me fait balayer toutes les critiques des spécialistes qui doivent bien trouver quelque chose à dire.Donc : Bon choix et de plus impressionnant comme je le souhaitais
review_date: Reviewed in France on 3 June 2019

one_reviews_text: I had a Rift CV1 for two years and had daily problems with the sensors switching off and trying to find optimal placement to attempt room scale. For me this was what I needed with the inside out tracking, no more head swimming drops or ugly black wires crawling up the walls.The resolution is fantastic, screen door is greatly reduced to the point of not noticing it and so are the god rays. The CV1 always had a soft look to the graphics due to the lower resolution, now everything is crisp and clear. The blacks are better too, as before a large dark area would be muddy and blocky now its just flat (almost) black.It is more comfortable to wear and quick to put on so good for Beat Saber parties.The only real big sort of gripe is the audio. At first I was confused as to why Oculus removed the rather splendid CV1 headphones, but to be fair I had to get my first CV1 replaced because the right headphone broke (which was apparently a common fault) and I think the decision to have built in sound holes was sensible. It does make it easier to share around without having headphones to deal with though. For more immersive gaming when the family are watching TV you can plug in some headphones, personally my SuperLux HD681 Evo headphones fit over the headset fine due to the design of the strap, and as a bonus the halo on the Rift S keeps the headphones off the ears so no pressure fatigue.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 23 May 2019
review_title: Mostly better than the original Rift

one_reviews_text: Oculus requires Facebook Account for data mining. Don’t buy if you value your privacy“ Today, we’re announcing some important updates to how people log into Oculus devices, while still keeping their VR profile. Starting in October 2020, everyone using an Oculus device for the first time will need to log in with a Facebook account. “
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 19 August 2020

one_reviews_text: Let me start off by saying this; I WOULD GIVE THIS A 5 STAR RATING ON BUILD QUALITY, FUN AND VALUE.However, I was completely unaware of the fact recently that Oculus (the designing company) was bought out by Facebook some time ago, and I didn't have any qualms with it. Not only this, but recent terms and condition updates from the Facebook have drastically changed the way I use this now seemingly useless paperweight.- By 2022/2023, it will now be a MANDATORY REQUIREMENT that you MUST own and link your facebook account to the headset, along with the Oculus account you need to make in order to use the software.- The integrated cameras in the headset, while not initially telling you at all, WILL SCAN YOUR SURROUNDINGS. This data is also sent off to Facebook for "profiling" it's users.- AT ANY TIME if you decide to deactivate/disable/delete your facebook account, any and all purchases made through the Oculus storefront WILL BE DELETED PERMANENTLY, without any hope of a refund.Unless you enjoy being a corporate shill, do not buy in this gimmick. while an inherently fun and unique experience, I can't say i enjoy the anxiousness of knowing my every move and sound i make is automatically recorded through this thing.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 26 October 2020
review_title: DO NOT BUY UNLESS YOU HAVE A FACEBOOK ACCOUNT

one_reviews_text: After an absolute promise from Palmer Luckey, founder of Oculus and the mega-corporation itself (Facebook) at the begining of their trade deal - Facebook has finally snaked their way into your living room by absolute force of hand, despite the absolute out rage of the public. Say hello to behavioral profiling and marketing to captive audiences. There is Zero benefit for the customer to not have choice and a potential danger in the new tech landscape to allow this to pass by unnoticed. I will be voting with my wallet and joining the thousands of others who will be leaving all oculus's services to the side. For Good"EFF analyst Karen Gullo sent me an additional statement via email: “The new requirement breaks a privacy promise to users. Facebook should be held accountable—keeping promises should be a minimum standard for new acquisitions.”""Privacy expert 'Jake Moore' cybersecurity specialist at ESET says the move seems “a blatant way to gain user connection information”, adding that “it is rather unusual to only offer one option when signing up.”
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 5 November 2020
review_title: WARNING:Oculus Forces all users to merge Facebook Account for privacy embreachments + mass profiling

one_reviews_text: Not for games like Echo Arena, or games where you require good sound, or fast tracking, or handing your hand behind your back. Screen Res is better than the CV1 and it looks great. The controllers are so cheap and light compared to the original touch controllers, this is absolutely a downgrade. Facebook wants to get these into as many houses as possible, and for general VR the Rift S might be good, for games like Echo Arena where throwing is important, this is a horrible downgrade from the original. Mine was also faulty.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 28 May 2019
review_title: Not for games like Echo Arena

one_reviews_text: Die Rift S wurde in der Presse ein wenig kritisiert, weil sie zu wenig "Fortschritt" im Vergleich zur Rift bietet. Jetzt wo ich sie Zuhause habe, bin ich anderer Meinung. Die Rift S ist ein gewaltiger Fortschritt. Klar, es handelt sich noch immer um eine kabelgebundene Brille, aber die Auflösung der Displays lässt die Pixel verschwinden und der "Fliegengitter-Effekt" ist kaum noch wahrzunehmen. Das Tracking funktioniert super, ohne aufwendige Kalibrierung und in jeder Richtung - die verschobenen Sensoren sind Vergangenheit.Alles in Allem eine in allen Bereichen bessere VR-Brille für einen sehr günstigen Preis! Im Gegensatz zur Quest hat man hier auch gleich eine gewaltige Menge an Software zur Verfügung.Klare Empfehlung!
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on 24 May 2019
review_title: Viel mehr Fortschritt, als ich erwartet habe!

one_reviews_text: Beautifully made piece of kit. I’d been promising myself this for some while (I’m 73 and want to “play”!) fairly simple (for non techie like me, to set up. Using Google Earth I am exploring my brother’s holiday to Canada and see the use, as they’re driving around, to have an idea of what their various hotels look like from outside so they’ll recognise it as they arrive nearby. Last night I “flew” a microlight for the first time, in my office!! The feeling are so real I was quite unsteady on my feet at one point. Such is the realism the headset and programme gives you. I recommend this product unreservedly.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 27 June 2019

one_reviews_text: After less than 6 months use it has started crashing repeatedly leaving a very disappointed 13 year old boy. Support from Amazon nill. Support from manufacturer laughable. Avoid this over priced crapUpdate: so started a return on this as it stopped working properly after less than 6 months. The Courier Collectplus( avoid these clowns too) which Oculus “ Support” instructed me to use “lost” the parcel, it was picked up June 1st then simply disappearEd (wonder did it end up on eBay?) . Collectplus advises me to contact Oculus and get them to raise a claim. I provided Oculus support with all the proof of dispatch tracking numbers etc on June 17th. Since then, despite daily emails, Oculus “Support” haven’t even the manners to reply. So through no fault of our own, I have a very upset child at home who got less than six months use out of his VERY expensive Christmas present. We followed the instructions from Oculus Support to the letter and because The courier which they contracted for the return “lost” my package we are left in limbo with no replies or acknowledgement. I cannot stress this enough AVOID this product. If something goes wrong you will get no support either from Amazon or the manufacturer.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 5 May 2020
review_title: Unplayable after 5 months use ZERO support
