one_reviews_text: Pues lo dicho, maravillosas gafas de realidad virtual para quién busque iniciarse en el mundillo de la vr sin desembolsar gran cantidad de dinero por una calidad más que decente.Sin sensores externos ni líos de usbs ni cables por toda la habitación, ponértelas y a gozal papito.Fácil e intuitiva configuración con una demostración de todo el potencial y lo que te espera en la realidad virtual.La calidad de los componentes es aceptable, si bien viene siendo plástico no es un plástico de los chinos o si pero de buena calidad, en todo caso es plástico chino del chino bueno no del malo, ya me entendéis.Las cámaras muestran tu alrededor en blanco y negro con una calidad digamos que decente( llámalo decente llámalo cutre) pero como su uso es solo para orientarte pues pa que más!.La ergonómia, bueno aquí todo depende de lo que uno considere cómodo o no y del cabezón que cada cual posea. En mi opinión son bastante cómodas si te las colocas bien( la parte de las lentes va en los ojos eh por si alguno se despista) hay veces que me las he puesto y la mar de cómodo y otras que no podía dejar de toquetearlas para colocármelas bien, yo que se depende como he dicho, eso si, sauna incluida con las esponjas calidad chino de barrio extra calor plus.Las lentes, vamos al meollo (expresión que no alcanzo al comprender pero la uso porque queda chachi) digamos que en mi caso lo que son los pixels de la pantalla los veía, y bastante. No entiendo a la gente que dice que no se llegan a apreciar si no te fijas(deben usarlas embadurnándolas de aceite), asi que en este caso aceptable sin más aún hay que evolucionar más en este aspecto.La definición, no te esperes un monitor 4k ni uno 1080p ni por asomo, esto como todo tiene que evolucionar pero al menos ahora puedes distinguir letras sin morirte en el intento y leer con claridad. Son paneles LCD por lo tanto menos intensidad en los negros y colores.El efecto glare, pues si otro de los efectos que la gente dice que apenas lo aprecian en mi caso si lo aprecio, lo veo y mucho en según que condiciones.Sonido, aquí ni me molesto en poner algo constructivo la verdad, son dos mini altavoces colocados en la diadema, ¿que esperas? pues calidad normalita tirando a lamentable. El microfono que esta incluido más de lo mismo, cumple y ya.EL CABLE, EL MARAVILLOSO CABLE.Pues bueno bueno bueno, aquí vamos a lo más preocupante y lo menos esperado por mi parte, el cable es un mierd**, ya no tanto el cable si no su posición y su forma de sujetarlo en la diadema. Se dobla, se dobla más que una contorsionista en una maleta de mano. He tenido que devolver mis oculus que aun con todas las pegas anteriores era un producto más que decente por su precio por el dichoso cable. Digamos que de doblarse lo normal nada de dobleces exageradas empezó a producir artefactos en las gafas. Si si, artefactos un cable que debe ser resistente a la fuerza por diseño, pues en 7 dias se empezó a escoñar. La próxima vez que me haga con un visor nuevo me cosere el cable al cuerpo para que se mueva lo menos posible.Los mandos, una maravilla sin duda lo que mas me ha gustado del conjunto en si, ergonómicos y muy cómodos e intuitivos el tracking funciona de lujo. Eso si siempre con la luz encendida.ACTUALIZACIÓN: segundas gafas que me toca devolver esta vez por polvo Dentro de la lente de vergüenza lo de oculus.
review_date: Reviewed in Spain on 1 August 2019
review_title: Maravillosas para iniciarse en este mundilo pero con una gran pega.

one_reviews_text: I hesitated for a long time between the original Rift and spending way more money for the Vive Pro. I had played with both, with the original Rift for several hours and I didn't feel comfortable with its limitations.  As soon as the Rift S was revealed, I knew that it could be a game changer, and it is. The screen door effect is gone, the graphics are sharper, better. In theory, we lost 10hz but it doesn't feel like we did because of the new display has less "ghosting" that the previous model.  The setup was a breeze; you don't need to dedicate a room for this as their are no sensors anymore. The pass-through mode is really useful, every time you want to start/stop playing the game.  The tracking is superb, I've heard some had issues with it but honestly, I don't. Just have a well lit room and make sure your PC has plenty of power to supply to the USB ports (disconnect other power hungry devices if you must).Two things could have been better; the sound, and the comfort of the headset. The sound can be re-mediated easily as there is now an audio jack on the headset, to plug your favourite earbuds. But the comfort of the "halo style" headband won't please everyone. I am ok with it personally, but it feels somewhat less comfortable that the CV1. But it is quick and easy to adjust so there's that.Overall, the simplicity of the Rift S and the compromises that were made to offer the best experience possible at this price are good with me. I like it a lot.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on 24 May 2019
review_title: Best VR headset on the market, price/performance wise

one_reviews_text: You will need a lot of good luck or some serious perseverance with good device management skills to even get your PC USB 3.0 (even with a dedicated USB 3 Card) to see the device and then you may have tracking issues. This is not plug-and-play. My old rift works fine. Also for me, the field of view is narrower. I still battle with the tracking issue and will update my review when I have a fully working device.Update: I returned the unit for a full refund. The experience was not good. On a positive note my original Oculus is as solid as ever.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 June 2019
review_title: Stick with your Rift and forget the S for now.

one_reviews_text: It took me a few hours to get this working as I kept getting a black screen. After much googling it turned out it didn't like some vulcan files installed with an AMD graphics card 4 years ago. Used AMD uninstall all and that fixed it. Using a 1080 ti graphics card and the visual quality is way above what I expected. I did want the index headset but I am glad I didn't waste my money on it now as this is less than half the price. Having used the rift, Vive and Vive Pro I would say this fits somewhere between the first two and the pro. It's so good though that I don't think it's worth forking out for the more expensive headsets. Tracking is great and the fact you do not need to mount any base stations is a big plus to me.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 5 June 2019
review_title: Major troubles getting it to work bit it was worth it. Fantastic visual quality and tracking!!

one_reviews_text: Increíble que, en 2019, Oculus lance un producto inferior a lo ya existente. Las compré el primer día, y las tuve que devolver.Yo tengo un IPD (distancia entre pupilas) alto (69 mm) y estas gafas tienen un IPD fijo (63.5) así que sabía que lo vería borroso en los bordes, pero como las PlayStation VR (que también tengo) tienen un IPD fijo similar y las veo bien, me arriesgué. En efecto el IPS fijo es un recorte con respecto a las Oculus Rift y otras gafas con IPD variable por hardware como las Samsung Odyssey Plus, pero aún así las veía bastante bien. Borroso en los bordes sí, pero con un buen punto dulce en el centro.Si fuese por el IPD me las hubiese quedado pese a no ajustarme a mí, pero me encontré con un problema que no esperaba: el FOV (campo de visión), la "ventana" que yo veía en las Rift S era MÁS PEQUEÑA que en las PS VR y las Lenovo Explorer (que también tengo).  En esas gafas ves una especie de círculo razonablemente grande, pero en las Rift S es un cuadrado más pequeño, como si mirases desde dentro de una caja.  Me sentía encajonado y los juegos no me aportaban la espectacularidad de las otras gafas, porque perdía inmersión. Como más IPD tengas, menos FOV ves, y eso se acentúa en las Rift S, al menos para mí.Así que al final las devolví.Si tenéis un IPD entre 61 y 65 mm y no os importan el FOV pequeño (creedme, importa), la calidad de imagen de la pantalla es muy buena, y el tracking, sensacional. Pero es bastante triste que Oculus haya lanzando unas gafas sin IPD por hardware y con un FOV tan pequeño, peores que otras que ya existen en el mercado, y más caras.Al final me compré  unas Samsung Odyssey Plus en Estados Unidos por 370 euros  y con el IPD por hardware y el FOV más grande, las veo perfectas y las disfruto mucho más, porque el campo de visión más grande aporta más espectacularidad.Decepción total con Oculus, que ha ido a peor y solo sirven para un porcentaje limitado de gente.
review_date: Reviewed in Spain on 15 June 2019

one_reviews_text: after 3 months and another 250 pounds spent on software i think this headset should never have been released in the state its in, after a whole 2 weeks where it wouldnt register the thing being plugged in they released an update. that allowed it to connect.  thing is it wouldnt work for more than 5 minutes until the sensors stopped tracking the controllers, the client said i had multiple right controllers that couldnt be removed, the games that used unreal engine crashed reliably after 3 minutes and support said try plugging it in again. then they said wait for an update. update arrived and yay the thing works... for 10 minutes  instead of 5. same issues. support said nothing at all this time. i said i want to return it they said wait for the update. they updated... guess what works for 15 minutes now... im done. i have lost faith with the whole idea of the hobby
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 1 September 2019
review_title: DO NOT BUY worst support ever

one_reviews_text: I had the oculus rift cv1 for 1 year, decided to upgrade to this one . waited a month to do my review.BEST **** DECISION OF MY LIFE .This VR awesomeness is incredible . GREAT capting of position in space. INCREDIBLE image. AWESOME INCREDIBLIBILIDIDLIDU system and the dash DOPE. The head comfort is absolute and the adjustements are allright.only cons : if you have a very small head . my girlfriend had a hard time adjusting the oculus rift s... but still it was good.love you oculus. the future is now.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on 10 June 2019
review_title: I cannot understand the people bashing it

one_reviews_text: At first when I set it up, my oculus rift set up smoothly. After about 30 minutes of playing suddenly the controllers stopped tracking well and the video went dark. The oculus rift requires usb 3.0, yet my usb 3.0 ports are running at 2.0 when I plug in the oculus. I've updated all my drivers, my motherboard, I reinstalled the oculus app and still the sensors are unable to track the headset. Overall it was great when it worked, but it stopped working all of a sudden and I'm very unsatisfied with the setup
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on 24 May 2019

one_reviews_text: History:  I owned the original Oculus Rift. Whilst it was working, it was fun, but then the problems started. Disconnects, black screening and random shut downs. After a second headset due to cabling fault, i thought this had been remedied. Back went that head set as well.Fast forward 2 years: Ordered the Oculus Rift S for release date. Out of stock on release date which was instantly a massive anti climax. When I did get my hands on the new Rift S, the setup started (or at least I thought i was going to do a setup).Following the setup guide, I updated my computer and graphics card and downloaded the Oculus interface. 4 hours later, I was still not online with my Oculus Rift S. At this stage, I decided to stop and try again with a clear head the following day. Still unable to connect the headset and trawling the internet for another 4 hours, I requested a return and ordered a new headset. Hopefully this will alleviate the problem and my star rating.I contacted Oculus help for assistance with diagnosing on Monday evening and still have not heard from anyone relating to the problems I was experiencing which goes to show the customer service is absolutely abysmal.I hope the replacement headset and controllers work first time, otherwise I will be requesting a full refund and taking my business elsewhere in the future.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 May 2019

one_reviews_text: L'oculus rift s rispetto alla precedente versione risulta di gran lunga più ottimizzato e ben pensato, eppure ancora non ci siamo. La mancanza delle basette per il tracciamento del movimento dell'utente è gradita oltremodo, infatti le odiavo, erano un continuo spostarle e riposizionarle. Inoltre, nel precedente oculus non riuscivo ad utilizzare in alcun modo i miei occhiali ed ero prossimo all'acquisto delle lenti graduate da porre nel visore, per fortuna non l'ho fatto ed ho preso questo rift s, nel quale ammetto che gli occhiali anche i più ingombranti ci stanno più che bene senza neanche appannarsi, infatti quelli della oculus han finalmente compreso che le narici del naso andavano isolate all'esterno del visore, il precedente visore infatti era un continuo appannarsi, senza tener conto della totale impossibilità di utilizzarlo con gli occhiali. I pregi però, finiscono quasi qui, infatti abbiamo un aumento di definizione tale da rendere il visore eccellente rispetto al precedente, ma il refresh rate peggiora notevolmente per un visore da porre a pochi cm dagli occhi.Per me però i difetti non finiscono qui, i giochi sono praticamente sempre gli stessi, da quando ho utilizzato il precedente rift l’ultima volta infatti, sono usciti soltanto 4 titoli nuovi degni di nota e parliamo di circa 4-5 mesi orsono, ma il problema di ogni titolo per visore virtuale è che durano pochissimo e costano sempre tanto, persino con le offerte dell'oculus store, il prezzo non scende mai sotto certe soglie tali da renderli accessibili a chiunque, ma io non riesco a comprendere la logica di queste persone, ma veramente non riescono a capire che 5€ per gioco invoglierà tante persone ad acquistarlo anziché 15-40€? E’ così difficile comprendere che se vendi un gioco ad un prezzo accessibile le persone che l’acquisteranno ti faranno guadagnare molti più soldi poiché l’acquisteranno in tanti? Ma quando vendi un prodotto ad una cifra esagerata, molti saranno scoraggiati dall’acquisto ed ecco il problema. Io non accetto di pagare 30€ per un gioco che nella migliore delle ipotesi mi durerà 3-6 ore.Mi rendo conto che chi acquista questi visori deve possedere un pc da urlo, e quindi si suppone che abbia soldi da buttare in giochi senza problemi, ma io no, ho un pc da 6000€, con una 1080TI, eppure non ho la benché minima intenzione di spender centinaia di euro per un tot di giochi che molto probabilmente alla fine saranno una delusione totale, e se poi non mi piace il gioco? Devo iniziare una trafila assurda per fare un reso? Sempre se sia possibile effettuarlo dopo averlo provato e giocato.Quelli della oculus ancora non capiscono come funziona il commercio e si lamentano se poi non sfondano i visori vr, fate pagare un botto di soldi per l'hardware, ma almeno investite in giochi decenti, i titoli degni di nota si contano sulle punte di un paio di mani, ed una volta terminati in un 3-4 mesi che ce ne facciamo di questi visori? Costosi soprammobili? Bella domanda.Ho provato titoli come climb, Avengers, robot recall, dead and buried, avrei voluto provarne altri, ma i costi erano per me assurdi e pure durante le offerte non erano fattibili, avrei voluto acquistare 5 giochi, ma anche quando c’erano i saldi il totale superava i 100€ e per me non se ne parla, anche se sono 5 i giochi, non pago una tale cifra per un gioco che poi finisce subito e non lo utilizzerò più.Per esempio, ho acquistato arizona sunshine, pensavo fosse un capolavoro ed invece delusione totale, si, carino e simpatico per certi versi, ma doppiaggio da bancarelle e giocabilità peggiore, ho acquistato altri 4-5 giochi su steam vr e li ho dovuti rendere tutti poiché avevano problemi di controller, visuale, giocabilità, longevità, grafica, persino the forest era ultrasgranato ed impossibile da giocare, veramente non potete capire il livello di pixel che si vedevano nel gioco, sembrava un minecraft finito male. Ah quasi dimenticavo, minecraft con il  vr, ecco una piacevole sorpresa, veramente non avrei mai pensato di poter giocare a minecraft in prima persona e vedere la spadina come se l’avessi in mano per davvero, ma il refresh rate basso del visore ogni volta che giravo la testa a destra o a sinistra, impiegava 2 secondi per renderizzare la visuale del gioco, nell’attesa avevo sempre la visione periferica che diventava nera a scatti.La cosa peggiore che però ho riscontrato in questo visore è però la lunghezza del cavo, infatti seppur durante la configurazione dell’oculus il visore mi consigliasse d’utilizzare una zona di almeno 2,40x2,40 metri, il cavo non consente di tracciare zone più grandi di 1,8x1,8 metri.Quasi dimenticavo un particolare incredibile rispetto al precedente visore, la telecamera posta sul visore, vi consente d’osservare il mondo intorno a voi senza doverlo togliere ogni volta, so che sembra una cosa da niente, ma credetemi, con il vecchio visore era un continuo incavolarsi perché si andava a sbatter da qualche parte e si perdeva di continuo l’orientamento spaziale, invece con questo rift s è possibile osservare tramite le telecamere ciò che vi circonda, di contro la scomparsa delle torrette rappresenta quindi un grosso pregio, ma anche un grosso limite, infatti queste telecamere non vi consentono d’utilizzare in modo agevole il rift di notte o al buio, infatti quando l’ho configurato a luci accese non ho avuto problemi, ma a luci spente non riusciva a comprendere il software, dove fosse posto il pavimento, ma una volta accesa la luce ho risolto tutto.La telecamera comunque non vi consente una visione a colori e nitida del di fuori, ma soltanto una visione in bianco e nero rallentata, comunque più che sufficiente per far qualsiasi cosa senza dovervi togliere il visore. Tutto sommato, se i giochi avessero un prezzo accessibile ed il cavo fosse più lungo, questo visore sarebbe un bestbuy incredibile, invece l’ho reso, purtroppo, e dico purtroppo, perché tutti i miei amici che l’han provato e, persino io, c’eravamo letteralmente tutti innamorati dell’esperienza virtuale che offriva, ma un prodotto del genere senza contenuti fruibili risulta veramente inutile, oculus dovrebbe decidersi a stringer delle partnership significative per portare i giochi virtuali ad un altro livello, per esempio, non immaginate quanto avrei voluto giocare a resident evil 7 con il visore, ma nulla di fatto, è esclusiva ps4, avrei voluto poter giocare a giochi fps in prima persona come crysis, ma nulla, non c’è alcun supporto, mi rendo conto che sia lavoro per quelli della oculus, ma che ci vuole ad immaginare quante persone pagherebbero fior fiori di quattrini per poter giocare con un vr giochi del genere? Io anche se ho già acquistato su steam e origin tutti quei giochi, li ricomprerei soltanto per poterci giocare con il vr.. Comuque alla fine l'ho reso a malincuore, sperando però che in un prossimo futuro i giochi siano più accessibili, che siano supportati anche giochi come RE7 ed altri e soprattutto che si decidano ad investire come si deve anche lato software e non soltanto hardware, perchè i giochi devono durare di più ed esser più coinvolgenti.
review_date: Reviewed in Italy on 15 August 2019
review_title: Funziona finalmente con gli occhiali, ma cavo corto, giochi che costano tantissimo e poca inventiva

one_reviews_text: Not gonna lie, I bought this purely for the Walking dead saints & sinners game.. I absolutely LOVE using this!  Also I was incrediby impressed that Amazon allowed me to pay in installments.Visuals are great, I was a little worried about the sound after reading online reviews, but it was more than great for me. It fits perfectly onto my head, and is stable. It also  has a nozzle that you can twist to tighten onto your head.The only issue that I have is that occasionally it will lose the ability to track the controllers when they are approx 180* horizontal with the headset, regardless of how bright, dim or neutral my lighting is. So with this is can be a bit tedious to unplug and restart up to 3-5 times.ONE HUGE TIP for buyers, is to ensure that you have a USB 3.0 port or higher, it will NOT recognise the device if you do not have one. I had to buy this seperately to ensure I could play on my gaming pc.Overall, a great product. My parents have even used it and were blown away.*P.S - Final tip*It is very likely that you will experience motion sickness when playing this for the first few times. What worked for me is drinking ginger beer, and to begin with small sessions of approx 10 minutes until you build up. Also, stop playing as soon as you begin feeling dizzy or sick, otherwise your brain will associate that feeling whenever you put this on.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 15 April 2020

one_reviews_text: UPDATE: I've sent it back for a refund. After trying out a Quest 2 for the same cost as this on sale (plus an extra £50 for an elite strap) I found there's very few reasons to take this over the Q2.The Rift S is slightly more comfortable to wear and tracks the controllers at a slightly wider angle by your sides than the Q2 but the Q2:- has interchangeable face masks so you can get the right fit-has better in-built speakers and on-board volume controls- has a higher resolution screen with noticeably less screen-door effect over the Rift S- has slightly larger touch controllers which are more comfortable to hold and the positioning of the Oculus and menu buttons means you're less likely to catch them when playing a game like Beat Sabre.- can be used as a standalone unit or as PCVR with a Usb3 cable- does not require a DisplayPort connection- can be used wirelessly for PCVR if you set up virtual desktop- supports controller-less finger and hand tracking on apps which allow it- has a higher 90Hz refresh rate vs the Rift S's 80HzI had to try the Q2 for myself because there was no straight answer as to whether the Rift S or Q2 is better, some would say the PCVR experience on the Q2 had more latency or even a bit less resolution but these were from time of release, and there's been a lot of improvements to the Q2 in the last couple of months. I had the same movement and tracking experience with the Q2 as with the Rift S, minus tracking the controllers further around my sides, but had much more clarity and only required 1 wire. And if I want to play VR anywhere in the house I can always put it in wireless mode and play where I want.If you're in doubt, the Quest 2 is a better headset in every area where it matters. There's no reason to buy the Rift S over the Q2 unless you already have an Oculus account and don't want to make a Facebook account before 2023. The constant USB driver issues were the final nail in its coffin for me, especially when you consider the Rift S will be discontinued next month so they're definitely not going to bother trying to fix these issues now.-------Original Review Below-------I can't really sing praises any more than others have already done.Having never used VR before this thing is a revelation and adds so much more to a typical gaming experience. Seeing things in your hands in VR for the first time is still a truly breathtaking experience and I'm still very pleased with this headset even though there are better ones on the market (like the Index, which costs 3 times as much as this).I have 2 major gripes though: the first is that cleaning this thing is a pain. If you play something active like beatsaber you are going to sweat, and all of it is going to soak in to the cushions on the Halo and the eye mask.Oculus recommends you use antibac wipes to clean them however this isn't going to clean them completely. Ive started wearing a sweatband on my head so I can just wash the sweatband instead.The second (and worst) major gripe is that the Windows drivers for the USB3 connection are trash. In my experience the Oculus client has to be reinstalled every couple of days, as every other boot the drivers will just malfunction and the app will refuse to detect the headset despite still providing power and windows detects it as a display device. Google searches reveal that this is a very common problem and has been going on since the Rift S was released, but the only resolutions are to deregister your headset and reinstall the oculus app, reinstall Windows or uninstall drivers in device manager and pray to the VR gods that it will be detected when you reconnect it. This wouldn't be an issue if you could use the headset without the app as the app seems to be the culprit, but you can't. The headset will not work without the oculus app being open.I'm persevering but I'm seriously considering returning it if it keeps doing it, as each time I sit down to play something in VR I have to spend an hour getting the app to actually recognise my headset, which isn't exactly how I want to spend my limited free time.Its a shame, as if it wasn't for this I'd be recommending everyone buy it as their entry in to VR, especially if you find the 1k+ prices of the others a bit too much to justify.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 December 2020
review_title: A great VR headset for the money, but the Quest 2 is better.

one_reviews_text: I wanted to to love the Rift S, but after two days of trying I just couldn't. I play only DCS flight sims, so YMMV.Pros:Great designGood weight distribution and comfortable to wear on the head (see cons beloe for how my face felt)Incredible ease of set up - plug and playFantastic bundles softwareBrilliant inside out tracking and easy to set upGreat colours and blacksLittle light bleedHeadphones are cool (they're hidden in the headband. I admit, I appear to be one of very few people who like them!)Cons:Cheap gasket sponge was uncomfortableNo physical pupil distance (PDS) set up means a) you have to measure your own, and b) you have to use software to configure it. At about 69 PD, I was right on the cusp of what the software could allow for (70 is the limit, I believe)The 'sweet spot' - the bit where you can actually see clear content through the fresnel lenses - was much smaller than I expected. This meant that I had to turn my head and keep my eyes fixed ahead if I wanted the object of interest to be in focus. Looking around with my eyes meant that most content not dead center in the screen was blurry.Returned my to Amazon for a refund. I may go for the Valve Index because it is supposed to have really good sharpness across almost all of the lens.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 October 2019
review_title: So close to being practical for my flight simming... but not quite there.

one_reviews_text: The Product is good, So it got a star. The problem is you have to join Facebook. I was not aware of this until I purchased the product. Emailed Oculus and told them I did not want to join, they said I had to if I wanted to use the product as it was made by Facebook, which I was not aware of!! Reluctantly joined Facebook just to be able to use the headset.  Two days later had my account in Facebook frozen, said I was not running it correctly, only had it two days and never used it, maybe that's what they mean by not running it correctly and they wanted me to send photo of myself for my account verification (not that they had any photos of me so don't know what that would prove?? Had enough, spoke to Amazon and explained and they were very helpful and agreed a return. So beware if you purchase an Oculus VR headset you will need to join Facebook whether you want to or not. I have now returned the product and will look for another product that is not so restrictive.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 3 January 2021
review_title: Do Not Purchase this item if you don't want to join Face Book

one_reviews_text: I've owned a CV1 for two and a half years without any seriously perplexing software or hardware issues (only multiple returns for earphones). My computer more than meets the hardware requirements for the Rift S so I foolishly thought installation and setup would be straightforward.However, when running setup the headset never gave any sign of life. The screens never lit, the white LED indicator never lit. The USB 3.0 of the headset was sometimes detected, but the display port never was. I have spent days messaging support back and forth. Eventually they told me to reinstall Oculus Home, but then that wouldn't install again, even though I've never had that issue before.Eventually I got Home to install and tried to setup up the Rift S, but again without luck. So I tried to setup my old CV1 again but now, despite the setup screens showing my HDMI and USB 3.0 inputs as being all present and correct it's showing a hardware error screen.After spending £400 I should have a new Rift S and an old CV1 but effectively what I've ended up with is no VR whatsoever. That's not what I call value for money. The Rift S will be returned for refund.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 19 June 2019

one_reviews_text: Having been to the Tim Peake exhibition @ Peterborough, they had Samsung VR goggles for the simulated capsule return.... When Rift S was announced, I put myself down with a pre-order beginning May.On the day it was advertised as being released, the box arrived with me in the afternoon!I had to beef up the Graphics card & made sure I had a PCE USB3 card... setup went well - except for... you MUST allow Windows 10 to grant access to applications to use the camera... if you disable this, the initial Oculus setup will fail with some obscure error about not finding the headset!There's quite a bit of software downloading to do.... but after it al... WOW!I love this thing - it does take some getting used to as it can induce some motion sickness... but with gentle used, you can get used to it...Elite Dangerous is now just something else!... and Project Cars 2 (once you get a wheel) is amazing... I have also played Echo One, which is just SUPERB
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 July 2019

one_reviews_text: Premesso che questa è una recensione a caldo, molto veloce e sintetica.Nonostante sia un videogiocatore appassionato di vecchia data ho atteso per provare la realtà virtuale.Ho pensato che adesso fosse il momento giusto e che ci sia della maturità nei prodotti.Il Rift S mi ha convinto e dopo giorni di attesa, a ridosso del lancio, l'ho ricevuto.Mi reputo un Power User e quindi sono abituato a procedimenti tutt'altro che lineari nel risolvere i problemi su una piattaforma Windows.Appena arrivato l'ho voluto mettere subito alla prova.Il primo grande ostacolo: questo prodotto è schizzinoso per quanto riguarda le porte USB 3. In base al chipset che avete sulla scheda madre potreste vedervi rifiutare di funzionare, sia a livello di installazione sia di funzionamento vero e proprio.Asus P9X79 e chipset AsMedia. Niente da fare, incompatibile con l'Oculus.Fortunatamente in casa avevo una scheda di espansione USB 3.0 PCI Express e finalmente tutto è stato installato correttamente e funziona alla perfezione.L'unico grande problema che lo rende inutilizzabile: non appena lo si indossa al di fuori dell'ambiente 3D inziale, quello dove si provano i cubi, il touch, le gestures, la racchetta da ping pong, il sistema si freeza di brutto e l'unica è spegnere e riaccendere.Questo avviene appena si indossa il visore. Adesso sto provando con dei titoli al di fuori di quelli Oculus per vedere cosa succede.Ho aperto un ticket presso Oculus, vediamo cosa dicono a tal proposito.L'esperienza comincia proprio male.Il sistema che utilizzo:CPU Intel i7 3820 3.6 GhzMB Asus P9x79 bios 4701RAM 16Gb DDR3 Dual ChannelGPU Palit NVidia GTX 1060 6GB Dual FanPSU Corsair HX650 650WSSD Samsung 830 256GB SATA3Scheda di espansione CSL PCI Express 2x USB 3.0 chipset Renesas/NECEDIT rapido del 30/05/2019Ho voluto aggiornare subito il voto a 5 perché sono riuscito a risolvere il problema.Il problema del freeze era quasi certamente imputabile al mio sistema.Ho avuto modo di recuperare una scheda madre gemella seppur in versione LE è bios 4801 anziché 4701 di quella inizialmente provata.CPU diversa, ovvero un i7 3930K e ram diverse, 8Gb Gskill rosse in dual channel.Anche questa con il maledetto chip Asmedia che gestisce le USB.Fortunatamente avevo dentro già la scheda PCI Express per l'espansione USB, con chip NEC.Il mio timore era che i freeze fossero dovuti proprio a questa e che avrei dovuto rivedere le stesse scene di blocco una volta indossato il Rift.SSD diversa con la stessa installazione di Windows 10 usata nell'altro sistema, cosa fattibile perché è la stessa motherboard con lo stesso chipset Intel X79.Dopo qualche incertezza nel rilevare la display Port ( me la dava scollegata) l'usb viene riconosciuta come compatibile.E rullo di tamburi, indosso il Rift, rassegnato e quasi certo che si sarebbe ripresentato immediatamente il blocco del sistema.Stupore. Niente blocchi, tutto perfetto e magicamente strabiliante come penso sia stato per tutto quando abbiamo indossato un visore VR per la prima volta.Sono stato credo 4-5 ore a dilettarmi a testarlo. Spettacolo!Seguirà a breve una recensione più dettagliata, con le mie impressioni sull'esperienza d'uso.Le caratteristiche alla fine potete reperirle ovunque.Un bel sospiro di sollievo per non doverlo restituire ad Amazon, che lo ha consegnato in anticipo!
review_date: Reviewed in Italy on 28 May 2019
review_title: Prima volta in VR, qualche tentennamento dovuto a incompatibilità, risolti nel migliore dei modi!

one_reviews_text: Ich habe bereits die Oculus Rift gekauft und getestet. Ich war begeistert von der Technologie! Jetzt habe ich mir die Rift-S gekauft und muss sagen, dass in gewissen Punkten eine Verbesserung erzielt wurden aber leider auch, dass in gewissen Dingen die vorhergegangene Version besser war.+ Keine Sensoren mehr zum Aufstellen nötig+ Weniger Kabel/ Auflösung (immer noch viel zu gering hier muss definitiv noch mindestens das 4 fache her)- Nur der Inhalt genau im Zentrum  der Linse wird scharf dargestellt, der Rest ist verschwommen.- Einige Programme (z.B. VRChat) funktionieren nicht ordnungsgemäß- Viele Bugs mit dem tracking der Controller (ab und zu zeigen sie in die falsche Richtung)Ich rate von einem Kauf ab.
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on 23 May 2019

one_reviews_text: So I have owned a HTC Vive for nearly 2 years, moving to the new rift s has been an amazing transition, why? let me break it down:PROS:1. Sensors are gone2. Tracking is still fantastic3. Just one cable(for the headset)4. All those nasty chargers and power cable have gone(2 for charging vive controllers, 2 for Sensors, 1 for the power box)5. The image quality is far better than my viveCONS:1. The audio is just not that good, but they said they are working on a software fix
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 May 2019
review_title: Owner of HTC vive, moving to oculus

one_reviews_text: Had a horrifying time trying to get a psvr / psmove / kinect / eye cam set up working in vr.. nothing but pain and wasted time / money... was worried sick about this Rift S kit being another ball-ache.. but nope, everything set up and updated first run, was going inside of 15 mins of unboxing, absolute win.  Have not played much at this point, might edit this review later.. but I will say, the visual quality of this HMD is stunning, the 3d depth and immersion, even the comfort, all just right on for me.. the controllers, work excellently.. only thing i noted was a slight shift with positional tracking over about an hours constant play, which frankly was not an issue.  The guardian system and switch to external cam view are excellent and should keep all but the completely stupid safe.  I dont often rave on about a product, but I have waited since the late 80`s for VR to really become a practical home thing and this most certainly qualifies for that achievement.  Thanks to Amazon for the quick ship and discounted price and thanks to oculus for having done such a good job on the kit, set up and functionality.  In one day, I`ve trained in a vr gym, boxed in a vr ring, manned a gunner pod on a space station, rode a motorbike whilst shooting bad guys and commanded my own starfleet vessel in battle against the klingons.. cant recommend this kit enough.. beautiful.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 24 August 2019
review_title: I`d call this a Roculus.. nice kit

one_reviews_text: I bought this headset specifically so I would not have to make a facebook account, but they simply tell you in the last stap after the long installation process, that you need a facebook account to use the headset. This is ridiculous.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 December 2020

one_reviews_text: My wife purchased this as a present. I have looking for over a year at VR options. This product matches my needs and  works very well with my PC. However, I was not please that I had to create a facebook account to start the setup stage. If this was not a gift would have sent it back.Not sure how true but there are now articles on the web that state this product is being withdrawn, Again would have sent it back EXCEPT that x-plane that I purchased in steam works well and that was one of my top 10 requirements. The free VR stuff is also very good with Google Earth VR being excellent (No 2 on list). Have to wait to see what support Oculus give to this product. Assuming that I will be able to use it over the next five years, i will keep faith with this product.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 11 January 2021
review_title: Hate being Force into creating Facebook account

one_reviews_text: Here's a summary of the most important pro's, con's and myths (in opinion).Pros:1. No external sensors to set up.2. Lightweight.3. Comfortable.4. Feels well built.5. Hand controls are sturdy and intuitive to use.6. Headset Connects with just one cable (with two connections to your PC).7. Wireless Handsets use just 1 x AA battery each (included).8. Setting up your safe play area means that you won't trip over the coffee table or hit the wall when playing...just be careful of the cat!Cons:1. Installation software is a bit clunky (took a couple of attempts even though we know our way round a PC and fault finding isn't always straightforward).2. The plug which connects the video lead to the headset is a bit loose on mine and I have to be careful not to bump it when putting the headset on or it disconnects (a cable tie to hold the leads in position on the headset has helped).Myths:2. The built in sound is poor. This isn't my experience at all; it's not like wearing headphones but it's more than adequate, the stereo separation is good (you can easily tell the direction of origin of a sound in the game) and the sound is clear.2. Resolution isn't great. Ok...so it's not 4k but it's very immersive with games like Pavolv VR and Elite Dangerous and there's a lot of free software to get you started. If you're in a game and standing on the edge of a building you won't want to step over the edge... it's convincing enough.3. VR games isolate you from the other people in the room. Not really... everything that you see in VR can be shown on the TV, so the family can enjoy it too (and shout advice while you're playing) or you can team up with friends who have their own VR sets.I would recommend watching a few videos online or reading several reviews before making your buying decision. I think this is a really fun piece of equipment and for me it was worth it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 October 2019
review_title: Generally a good piece of equipment, just do your research and manage your expectations.

one_reviews_text: This HMD was my first into vr from phone vr and my first word in the first steps tutorial was "oh my f***Ing god!" To experience depth in vr is so cool and to have hands. text was super clear at a close - mid range but got blurry after far my favourite games right now are rec room and Pavlov and i can spend 2+ hours in vr without getting sick or uncomfortable ( may vary on your personal preference ). First I did not think it was worth £400 but after some time I've made new friends, explored the world in Google earth vr, had exercise dodging and crouching, watching movies in big screen, and more.Onto the bad things now :( It didn't come with a microfiber cloth to clean lenses and most people will clean with a shirt or other cloth wich can leave annoying scratches but I had one alreadyWith my head the headset tends to tilt upward and makes heath bars or HUD information that's on the bottom hard to seeBattery life depends on the brand but I bought a 30 pack of aa from Poundland for £2 and has lasted me over 2 weeks with some still leftWith my current pc my CPU can't handle vr very well I know this is my problem but make sure your specs are within range I have a pentium g4560 and gtx 1060 6gb and my CPU is at 100% usage and I get frame drops to the 30s and below and makes everything look like jelly wiggling and glitching to make up the lost framesOverall: extremely good purchase and worth the money just look after it and buy a few accessories for it, also set up took less than 15 mins super easy, my mum had a go and was amazed aswell
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 26 October 2019

one_reviews_text: Go Vive. Unless..you don't care about buying AA batteries every week.You don't want a decent configurable vr platformYou love Facebook and have a Facebook accountYou hate really good trackingYou're lucky enough to own a PC with a 3.1 USB connectioneurgh, so bad.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 18 November 2020
review_title: VR is great, just not with Oculus I'm afraid

one_reviews_text: This is one of the only high end VR headsets out there, it is very fun to use but has some very obvious issues.The tracking isn't the best, if you put your controllers down the hands go everywhere, the off-hand tracking is terrible.Playing sports games isn't that good because the headset slips away from your eyes a lot of the time.If you're doing something with high exercise expect to have a lot of mist in your goggles, this has become a hassle - constantly having to take off the headset to clean the mist out.Although there are very apparent issues with this headset it is still fun to use, I enjoy my time on the VR headset (When I get on it like, every week) the price is a bit steep, I'd say they should lower the price, from a hands-on perspective I'd say if I could go back I would pay around £240~300 for this (because of the very, once again, apparent issues.)EDIT: Enjoy spending £50 on batteries a month! GET THE STEAM VR INSTEAD!
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 14 September 2019

one_reviews_text: First of all THIS IS LONG BUT IN DEPTH. Also i have not received this free i used my own hard earned/borrowed from a credit card cash to buy this and it is just the opinion of someone who plays vr a bit to much.So there has been some good and bad reviews for this over the last few months and i thought i would throw my 2 pence worth in. So as a rift cv1 user for over 2 years and that is by and large using it at least once a day i absolutely love this headset. There are 2 niggles with it one of which is slightly resolved by windows believe it or not. So ill break this down into sections.Unit it self – the upgrade unit feels lighter then the cv1 and is very comfortable to use. The padding is very good on all areas of it. It is remarkable easy to put on me and 3 of my friends have used this over the last 3 days and they all agreed that so much less adjusting was needed to get it to where it comfy. The controllers are also nice to use. Pass-through mode is very useful for repositioning yourself during a active game or grabbing a drink or hand full of sweets while the game is loading Screen/visual – as I say 3 of my friends have used this as well and the first thing they said when entering VR was “oh wow” we all agreed that the increase in overall look is very good and definitely enough to class this as an upgrade and not just 'a minor change'  that screen kicking out the improved visuals is an LCD panel and this is where niggle number one comes in, because its an LCD blacks are not that deep and seem to have sort of a haze to them however this is only massively apparent in areas where there are LOTS of black for the most part it is definitely liveable. With the rift s there is a reduction in refresh rate to 80hz from 90hz. THIS IS NOT APPRENT we played some intense games including but not limited to project cars 2 and elite dangerous on maxed out graphics both of which ran buttery smooth.Sound – Ok so the sound here is a bit of a touch subject. This has no headphones like with the rift CV1 and instead used small speakers just above your ears. This has 2 problems firstly others in the room can here what’s going on a lot more then they could with the CV1 and secondly....they are just not that good. Sometimes with the cv 1 i found myself tilting the headphones away because it was a little too immersive ...normally late and night but the audio was still good with these however it is a little poor. I have partially made this liveable as i mentioned earlier by enabling loudness equalisation in the sound settings on windows however I feel I will now be looking for a sound alternative.Tracking – i have read some things online and in forums  about tracking issues and also about an apparent patch fix. In any case the tracking is as near as perfect no real setup in terms od tracking and it just works is all that can be said really. A word on setup here, this has been greatly improved namely the guardian setup. The clunky walking round the room with the headset has gone and been replaced with a system that is A LOT More accurate. This can only be described as using a giant purple sharpie marker to draw around the perimeter of your area. It takes seconds to complete a definite improvement.Overall i would hand on heart recommend this 1000 percent. I’m more than certain that both cv1 owners and new rift owners will be very impressed with this as long as they go in aware of the niggles outlined here.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 8 October 2019
review_title: This is a long one....but detailed

one_reviews_text: Prior to November 2019, the Oculus Rift S was the go-to headset for PC games. It was light, comfortable to wear, had impressive tracking that didn't require sensors, and boasted great visuals. If you wanted to play Arizona Sunshine, Stormlands, or Asguard's Wrath (in addition to one of the hundreds of Steam/Oculus library titles) then this was your pick.However, in November, Oculus made this headset redundant to most VR gamers and that is because they updated the Oculus Quest (which is a VR headset that doesn't require a PC - i.e. it has its own operating system) so that it can now be plugged into a PC and function as an Oculus Rift. All that you needed was a USB C cable, which cost about £10-£15 from Amazon.This meant that anyone with an Oculus Quest now had both an Oculus Link when they were travelling and an Oculus Rift when they were at home near their PC. If you are playing something like Beat Saber or Robo Recall then the Oculus Quest offers a far superior experience as you don't have a wire pulling you around. If you are playing something like Asguard's Wrath that requires a wire, then you have to put up with it on both the Quest and the Rift. So neither wins out.If it also very clear to us VR consumers, that Oculus has gone all-in on the Oculus Quest (with updates to the firmware coming about once a month) compared to the Oculus Rift that is slowly being forgotten about.The only real reason to buy an Oculus Rift S going in to 2020 is for the added level of comfort. Because there is no battery or additional hardware to run the operating system (like in the Quest), the headset is much smaller and lighter (I've added a compassion photo). If you are a VR power-user, using VR for 2-3 hours at a time then the Rift S might be something you consider for that comfort-factor if you really don't see yourself enjoying the cable-free experience or ever taking the VR headset to a friend/family member's house to show it off.For me and most people I've spoken to, the Oculus Quest is the choice of headset to get in 2020 if you are willing to spend over £350 on a VR headset. If the Oculus Rift S drops to £200-£250 anytime in the future, the Rift S might make sense to some people who want VR on a budget. I think we're a way off from that though.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 December 2019
review_title: A great headset made poor value compared to the Oculus Quest's Link feature

one_reviews_text: and Facebook recently decided to sink the ship by deciding you'll need a Facebook account to use it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 8 September 2020
review_title: Smells awful, nightmare to set up, software breaks constantly

one_reviews_text: Having previously owned the original Rift, I was really looking forward to owning one of these, but it turned out to be an utter waste of time and a pure disappointment.On the first day it took me 5 hours of faffing around to get this working, to play it for an hour, the following day, after having made no changes whatsoever to my PC after originally getting it working, it decided not to work again, after 4 more hours of faffing around, contacting oculus support, and trying for another 2 hours the following day, still no resolution, by the looks of things I'm not the only one facing these issues, there are dozens of others, those who have working headsets are the lucky ones!! The technology in itself when its working is fantastic, I can’t take that away from Oculus. BUT the faf you have to go through just trying to get this working is utterly ridiculous and Oculus support is a waste of time, mine is going back!If you would like to waste 11 hours and £400 quite easily please feel free to buy one, but you are better off saving your time, taking £400 in cash and flushing it down the toilet. My recommendation save up more money and get a HTC instead!! I have a couple of mates with Vive’s and they swear by them and say there is no faf and they’re fantastic, wish I had listened to them in the first place, saved up more, and got a Vive, which is what I’m going to do now.I'm not normally one to write horrible reviews, but this is the worst piece of "technology" I've ever had the misfortune of owning, the "Support" is a joke and the Rift S would work better as a paperweight!
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 December 2020
review_title: Don't waste your time and money!

one_reviews_text: Wie gesagt, meine erste VR Brille. Daher kann ich keine Vergleiche zu anderen Produkten dieser Art ziehen.Aber ansich bin ich sehr zufrieden. Die Verarbeitung wirkt gut und das Gefühl wirklich in die Spielewelt einzutauchen ist definitiv da.  Meine Brille ist auch kein Problem. Nur darauf achten das man mit dem Gestell nicht direkt an die Linsen der VR Brille kommt. (Man kann denn Abstand einstellen)Die Installation war relativ einfach. Software runterladen (waren glaube ich 12 GB) wenn einem Bescheid gegeben wird  Headset anstecken an denn Computer und beim ersten aufsetzen wird man mit einer kleinen interaktiven Einführung ersteinmal an das ganze herangeführt.Anschließen muss man natürlich noch vieles herausfinden und Googlen. Versuche nach 3 Tagen immer noch herauszufinden wie ich Youtube 360 Grad Videos abspielen und die URLs dafür sammeln kann.Auch in Spielen muss man ersteinmal schauen welche Grafikeinstellungen man tätigt.Ich betreibe die Brille an einem Acer Predator G5-793 Notebook mit einer Geforce GTX 1060 Grafikkarte.An einigen stellen merkt man dann schon das etwas mehr Power ganz nett wäre, aber die meisten Spiele haben sichselbst erstmal so eingestellt das sie damit liefen. Wobei beim Manuellen nachregeln noch einiges mehr drin war.Also mein Rat, ausprobieren und selber die richtigen Settings finden.Wenn man bei Steam VR oder im Oculus Store nach Spielen und Software schaut rate ich dringen zum lesender Bewertungen, es gibt auch viel Schrott zu kaufen. (In Steam ist vieles günstiger zu haben, also beide Checken wenn euch was interessiert)Alles in allem merkt man relativ schnell das es viele Ecken gibt an denen man das ganze Hard und Softwaremäßig weiter entwickeln kann, was auch sicher in denn nächsten Jahren gemacht werden wird.Nicht falsch verstehen, es ist jetzt schon ein grandioses Erlebnis mit den richtigen Spielen, aber es wird mit zukünftigen Generationen der Hardware sicher noch wesentlich eindrucksvoller.Gutes Beispiel ist der Taucherbrillenblick denn man immer hat. Da die Displays vor denn Augen sind hat man trotzdem wie mit einer Taucherbrille einen kleinen schwarzen Rand bevor das Sichtfeld losgeht. Aber sobald man sich daran gewöhnt hat nimmt man das ganicht bis kaum noch war.Das Angebot an Spielen ist auch noch überschaubar, aber langsam kommt es in gang und es kommen neue größere Titel nach und nach dazu. Gibt auf jedenfall schon einiges Spielenswertes.Minuspunkte:- DVD mit Software wäre für manche sicherlich einfacher.- Microfasertuch zum Linsen abwischen wäre ganz nett als dreingabe gewesen.- Eine Vorinstallierte Software wie Virtuel Desktop oder eine Art Youtube VR mit eigenen Favoriten für  VR und 360 Grad Videos wäre nett gewesen.Anmerkung:Motion Sickness. Habe bei denn ersten Benutzungen Kopfschmerzen bekommen. Aber glaube da daran das man sich eingewöhnt wie es häufig zu lesen ist. Sollte man sich evt. zu einlesen,IPD. Gehöre nicht zu der Sorte die wirklich das Handbuch durchgelesen hat. Wenn ihr das auch nicht gemacht habt,unter Einstellungen gibt es einen Regler für denn Pupillenabstand (IPD). Hier sollte man wirklich beim Optiker mal messen lassen. Falsch eingestellte werte führten bei mir am Anfang zu sehr überanstrengten Augen.Wenn ihr einen Brillenpass habt könnt ihr auf da schauen, unter PD sind zwei werte die jeweils denn Abstand der Pupille zur Nase angeben. Ergo zusammengezählt = IPD
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on 23 May 2019
review_title: Zufrieden mit meiner ersten VR Brille

one_reviews_text: As of day one I tested a bunch of things on the Rift S, and there are a lot of things I like about the Rift S and some that I don't like.Pros so far:- Display is better looking that the original Rift.  - The slight drop in refresh rate hasn't been noticeable at all for me at least.- Out of box face pad is much more comfortable.- Inside out Tracking is great so far. (still need to mess with it more but haven't had any issues.- Throwing items in VR feels much more normal then the original Rfit. (I've noticed that the old method I used of pushing items to throw doesn't often work but a normal throwing motion seems to work great.... I tried this a lot in Super Hot.- (Update 5/24/19) Built in speakers - While not perfect for someone casually playing the built in speakers work well enough to play most games without issue. It sounds like its almost not playing anything for someone outside the headset but for the wearer it perfectly audible. Lacks good base though.Cons:- Ordered a 10ft display port extender and it seems to cause the black display issue that many are reporting.  - Removed the extension cable and haven't experienced it again yet- Halo head band is pretty thick and I feel alot of headsets will have a hard time getting around it. (I use a Man O War and it barely made it over the headset)- The weight distribution feels a bit odd but it is a new headset so it might take some adjusting to. (Not sure if this is really a con yet).- Cable length is a bit shorter than I would like for my play space.Overall I think it was worth the purchase and plan to rack up some hours with the new headset. Ordered a 6ft cable to some testing with and hopefully that will work without black screening. Updates to come! :D
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 May 2019
review_title: Overall happy with my upgrade from the original Rift.

one_reviews_text: This was a gift for my teenage son, it worked great at first, and was easy to set up. Although we didn’t like that you had to use a Facebook account, we did know this before we bought it though. Batteries in controllers ran out extremely quickly and I didn’t like that you couldn’t just switch these off. So, it started playing up a little and Oculus support was useless!! Raising tickets and never getting a response. The product after 6 months stopped working, wouldn’t recognise the headset, then it said it did but you couldn’t visual anything, although you could still hear the sound. Again Oculus were beyond useless!! I had a live chat with Amazon customer service, then with technical support and they both offered amazing customer service. Amazon agreed a refund due to the manufacturer being pants. 5 stars for Amazon, I would have rated the product and manufacturer no stars, but you have to put up at least one.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 18 July 2021

one_reviews_text: I can actually see the improvement in the graphics, not having the external sensors is a big plus. Even the headband is comfortable. The mic is remarkably responsive (tiny little hole - how DEOS that mange it).So why dropping a star, remember this is subjective. I used to use an external (SteelSeries) headset, while this >can< be done it is a bit of a faff and does make the headband a bit awkward and tight. I know that the headband can be removed and maybe I'll eventually have some alternative - maybe hanging onto the headphones themselves. The sound itself is OK - not as good as a dedicated headset.Would I go back? No, the visuals are good, I can work with the audio - just. Not having the external sensors is great - although I HAVE had a few dropouts - bad news when hacking across the solar system (Elite Dangerous)!
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 19 June 2019

one_reviews_text: J'avais essayé le Samsung Gear VR mais là le niveau est cent fois mieux. Enfin la VR est arrivée à un point intéressant (qualité/fonctionnalité/prix) pour tout le monde. Très simple à utiliser, à paramétrer et à jouer. Très bon tracking des mouvements, pas mal de jeux et parfois franchement physique. Je recommande à toutes et tous d'essayer.  Seul point un peu négatif, le prix des jeux est encore un peu élevé, mais avec Steam on peut trouver des jeux pour moins cher.
review_date: Reviewed in France on 30 May 2019

one_reviews_text: Ce casque VR n'est ni plus ni moins que le reflet d'une technologie qui se cherche. A force il n'y aura plus personne pour l'acheter... L'ergonomie très pratique est vraiment bien pensée tout est simple et l'immersion prenante. Mais voilà ..de la buée arrive au bout de 20sec si vous portez des lunettes et l'image reste toujours Très en deçà d'un écran de la XBOX 360 sans câble HDMI. si l'immersion est votre seul objectif vous pouvez l'acheter. Si vous avez déjà un Oculus vous serez déçu car la différence ne justifie pas un nouvel achat...
review_date: Reviewed in France on 6 June 2019

one_reviews_text: To ne clear the rift s isn't a terrible headset by it's own merit but just a bad option at the moment given the alternatives.The quest 2 is the same price, supports pc vr using either a USB cable, virtual desktop or air link (coming very soon) which means you can play pc vr wirelessly. On top of that, it has a much crisper screen with 50% higher resolution, adjustable lens widths, and smoother 90hz (soon 120hz) refresh rate.Add to that the fact that less demanding games can run natively on the inbuilt hardware and there's really no advantage to buying a rift.If you just want to plug the headset in to your pc and go then the rift s works fine. But you're better off with the quest 2 for the same price + £100 for a good router and headband. It's still well worth the extra cost for these two accessories.I had to return the rift s due to the terrible visual quality and the motion sickness cause by the non adjustable lenses.Just get a Quest 2.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 April 2021

one_reviews_text: So I bought a rift S and VR is a lot of fun and extremely immersive. I had a week of enjoyment  and discovery, playing different games in VR. Unfortunately, little over a week of playing and the game crashed and the screen froze on the oculus. After restarting my PC the screen now refuses to turn on. When i put on the headset I am met with a black screen and the oculus program alerts to me that there is a hardware error. I have tried every solution that the tech support has advised (it is very vague and frankly embarrassing for a major tech company, I had an issue installing games that I had bought on there store as they were being blocked by a anti-virus software I don't have) and nothing worked. I've updated every driver, rebooted the oculus app, repaired the app, restarted my computer and plugged it out and back in again multiple times. Hopefully I can get a replacement but my experience has been so awful I should have bought the Valve Index instead.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 23 December 2019
review_title: Good for a week then stopped working. Tech support and customer support useless

one_reviews_text: Brought this as my first step into PC powered VR, honestly no complaints. Looks amazing, fits snugly, so much fun! Went for this headset as I don't have the space to set up the trackers other headsets require. The built in camera tracking works amazingly, I can bring my controllers right up to my face and swing around quite happily.I would suggest grabbing yourself a silicone protector to put around it as it makes the headset easy to clean after sweaty sessions hahaThere has been issues with some peoples hardware like the motherboard not recognizing the USB 3.0 input, and this headset didn't work with my old set up, so for anyone with a similar build to mine, it works like a dream.MSI MPG Z390 Pro Carbon, i9-9900k, 32gb Corsair Vengeance Pro, MSI RTX 2080 Super.I was on the fence about getting this or the Vive Cosmos, but honestly the higher cost isn't worth it just yet.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 August 2020
review_title: Awesome quality. Great if you don't have space to set up base stations

one_reviews_text: I have a Vive and a Rift S. Wasn't expecting much of an upgrade, bought it because its new and i wanted it... but the screen picture both clarity (sharpness) and resolution is a massive increase in my eyes. Also the sweet spot is huge compared. I couldn't believe how much clearer the picture was compared to the Vive and Original Rift (friend has one). The tracking seems on par with my Vive and its very simple to set up. Controllers are far better as they actually have analog sticks instead of silly track pads. Only downside like people say is the audio isn't great (but the Vive didn't even come with speakers) and you can just plug headphones in easy enough. Highly recommend to Vive owners on the fence. I will now be selling my Vive as i cant go back to it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 29 May 2019

one_reviews_text: I'm writing this after owning it for the last month. I use it almost exclusively for sim racing titles (Assetto Corsa and RFactor 2), and for that it is amazing. Not perfect as the resolution could be better, but it's definitely good enough for me, and a higher resolution would require significantly more GPU power to maintain a decent frame rate (vital to avoid motion sickness).Surprisingly comfortable to wear even for hours at a time, and the Guardian system is very helpful, preventing you from smashing into your living room furniture (although as I use it mainly for sim racing I'm usually sat down).More than anything else though, this just brings an entirely new level of immersion to sim racing. It is simply unbelievable. Load up Assetto Corsa (with the Sol mod), enter a race at sunset, at Spa with a grid full of GT3 cars and prepare for your jaw to hit the floor. It's not something you can really describe, you just have to experience what that extra dimension gives you, to be sat in the car with everything life-size. Absolutely amazing.If your PC can handle it and you enjoy sim racing, just buy one immediately.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 12 February 2020

one_reviews_text: This thing is mint.  I have a 4790k @4.6  with a gtx970 at stock speed.  That’s the minimum amount of graphics card that you could get away with.  Games like half life alyx are beautiful, and look fantastic on the pretty decent screen.  But I could barely run it at the lowest settings.  Most things will run though, with a bit of tweaking.  Doesn’t generally work very well with steam vr running, again could be more my issue.  VTOL vr being the only exception I can think of.  Massive software library to choose from, both steam and oculus, with loads of choice, so it’s not all shoot shoot.  I use mine for iracing predominately, but I’ll give almost anything a go.Good fit, not too heavy and comfortable for extended sessions.  Face foam is ok, but a cover is essential as it can get warm in there.  My son has a stigmatism, and he feels ill after using it, so much so he had to go to bed to try and sleep it off.  I really like mine and have had so much fun using it.  It can feel like another world at times, almost magical.  Sat on a racing grid, in the bucket seat, full size, real life all around you.  You can look over to your left, you’re looking out of your car and at a racing Ferrari, or stock cars at Daytona 500, cars as big as life.  It still blows me away everytime I put it on.Now, it can feel a bit early access, if you catch my drift.  It can occasionally be a pain when it disconnects, and also when you randomly have to set where the floor is and set the room boundary.  You can’t see where your dog/cat etc is whilst using it.  There is an option to see the room through the cameras in black and white, it’s just clear enough.  That doesn’t help when your eyes tell you you’re going one way but your brain disagrees on your way to your backside.  So be careful.  I have punched my telly at least 10 times.I have one red permanently lit pixel, I might send it in for fixing before my warranty ends, and one of the two battery cover magnets fell out.  It still works fine with the one, but not as securely as the cover with 2 magnets.  Other than that I can’t think of what else to say.  If you got this far, congratulations, and I hope you enjoy it like I do.  Take care, tata.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 25 March 2021

one_reviews_text: Very happy with the headset. Resolution, text sharpness is noticeably better than Rift CV1 :)I'm using arctis 7 wireless headphones and they fit perfectly
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 May 2019

one_reviews_text: My second foray into VR, I previously had a Samsung on phone device which was incredibly fiddly in use so, I gave up.Within the Oculus environment the Rift S it works OK although it did require reconnecting sometimes to be detected. Despites having a reasonably high spec set-up & graphics card I was disappointed with the graphics quality; for instance with Google Earth, trees & water were very fuzzy & the initial training modules were very granular - not in the slightest like the real world. I'm obviously expecting too much. I'm not a gamer & this is a device for gamers who are used to living in a coarsened world.I got the Rift S specifically for use with MS Flight SImulator which has just launched a VR capability. This was nightmare like something from the days of WIndows 95 with the pilot starting off sitting below the aircraft with black stencils floating around the screen which was broken into fragments. Lots of suggested fixes on the web involving registry mods., binding things & flying with your head out the cockpit. Come on  chaps it's 2021, we now expect stuff to work tolerably well straight out the box. I suspect I've been naive& too optimistic as MSFS has only just launched VR capability & MSFS is not yet an Oculus supported app. but I want the device working with MSFS NOW not in mid year.I'm returning the Rift S & will wait a few months until there are lots of glowing reports on the MSFS Forums commending VR headsets that work well out the box.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 1 January 2021
review_title: Okish within Occulus Environment but Hopeless with MS Flight Simulator unless you're an Anorak

one_reviews_text: Das Oculus Rift S ist für den Preis von ~450 Euro ein deutlich günstigerer Einstieg in die VR Welt als andere Headsets.Positives- Die Einrichtung ist sehr einfach, Display Port und USB Kabel anschließen, Oculus Software starten und den Anweisungen folgen.- Der Tragekomfort des Headsets ist sehr gut, auch für mich als Brillenträger. Es dauert nur wenige Sekunden eine komfortable Position einzustellen.- Tracking funktioniert einwandfrei, trotz der fehlenden externe Sensoren lassen sich bekannte VR Spiele wie Beat Saber, Star Trek: Bridge Crew, Super Hot VR oder Job Simulator einwandfrei spielen.- Wenn man sehr genau hinschaut, kann man die etwas höhere Auflösung (im Vergleich zu anderen Headsets) des Rift S sehen, die niedrigere Bildfrequenz (80 statt 90 Hz) bemerkte ich nicht.Negatives- Die neuen Controller sind zweckmäßig, könnte aber besser unterscheidbar gebaut sein. Mehrmals habe ich erst spät gemerkt, dass ich sie vertauscht hatte.- Die integrierten Lautsprecher sind ziemlich nutzlos, da wenig immersiv, Beat Saber macht so keinen Spaß. Entweder In-Ear Kopfhörer anschließen oder externe Boxen / 5.1 Anlage verwenden.Da die negativen Seiten leicht zu verschmerzen sind bzw. es Abhilfe gibt - 5 Sterne.
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on 21 May 2019

one_reviews_text: In short and after many days of research, forum reading, trial and error it seems that the power requirements of the Rift S is above and beyond that which can be provided via USB 3.0 and Displayport.  End result?  Random disconnects, Displayport or USB error messages all which result in you running around like a headless chicken trying to fix it when essentially, you can't fix it.  It is an Oculus fault.  Fairplay to Amazon - they sent me another within 48 hrs to assess whether this was a one off incident with my headset but guess what............................  We even tried it on multiple PCs in the house - an i7 7700k, an i3570k and an all singing all dancing monster machine - i9 9900k, 32gb RAM, GTX 1080ti.  Made no difference - the traits were the same everywhere.  Go onto the oculus forums and you will see that if you purchase this, you WILL join a long line of sufferers.  Don't bother.Guest a Quest 2.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 January 2021
review_title: Awful! - end of line, shoddy hardware, little support from oculus

one_reviews_text: A big step in sharpness and clarity from the original Rift, really pleased.  The lenses are also a huge improvement for sweet spot and reducing flare around bright objects.  The inside out tracking is super solid and coming from a 3 camera setup with the original Rift this is compatible but without the wires around the room.I sold my original (CV1) Rift with the cameras to get this and it is definitely a worthwhile upgrade.  The visual clarity, sharpness, brightness and text readability are a significant step up.  The colours and contrast pop now which I always wanted from my original Rift.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 24 May 2019
review_title: A big boost in sharpness and text readability from the original Rift CV1

one_reviews_text: Great games, you can buy both from Oculus or use the Viveport. Very confortable, more than the oculus go I used to have. However it seems many people recomends quest. I have not got Quest, but it does not need a computer, so you can bring it everywhere. However big games need computer. The games are impressing.Bad things: The shape makes very difficult to use headphones, only the small earphones you put in the ear, not the ones with arc. However you can use the standard output of the computer, so I use my soundbar.One friend of mine, complained about the problem about the glasses, he loved the rift, but we could not put the glasses inside. At the end, he enjoyed best the the go only because he could use the glasses.I would love to use the firefox, like in the go (and I guess the quest, however I am not sure about it), oculus rift provides the desktop application which allows you to see the computer screen, and so the navigator, but the firefox and youtube oculus go standalone applications where very cool. I miss them in my rift.so: Rift s for incredible games, go, for multimedia and casual programs and being portable. Quest, the advantages of both but less powerful than the rift.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 5 December 2019

one_reviews_text: I waited a long time to get a VR headset. I had no doubts that I wanted one and this was it. Unfortunately the reality was so different. Don't get me wrong VR is just astounding but the same cannot be said for the headset. It was beset by niggling problems from day 1 but niggles I was prepared to live with as I had no idea that they were niggles. Then the earphone jack on the side started acting up and getting steadily worse until it did not work at all. I got in touch with Oculus and explained the situation... and explained the situation and explained the si... you get the idea. I described the fault symptoms again and again to seemingly different people each time and none of them were listening. Eventually they agreed and I sent it off for a warranty repair and a 2 - 3 business day return... Five weeks later I get it back and a generous £15 for my troubles. An after sales service second to none because none would have been better.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 5 November 2020

one_reviews_text: I owned CV1 couple of years back and sold it as I had a lot of issues with the sensors breaking and overall tracking always being iffy.I'm glad to see that Rift S definitely addressed the wonky tracking. Not a big fan of the new controller design, but I'm sure I'll get used to them. The only thing that I'm really bothered by is the lack of headphones, meaning that to experience the best of VR, you need to shill out some more cash to get a decent headset.All in all, I believe it's definitely worth the upgrade if you're still using CV1 or have got rid of it and didn't pick up a replacement VR headset.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 31 August 2020

one_reviews_text: Hi.I am not saying this is bad product, just did not work out for me. here is why.Please be aware that expectations when purchasing this VR Headset might be quite high - nice videos online, good Oculus presentation etc.Reality is slightly different. None of the videos will show the actual image quality as seen by human eye in headset.My PC has EVGA GeForce RTX 2080 which renders beautiful image quality on multiple 1440p monitor set up with most games holding average above 120 FPS on HIGH graphic settings. I expected that VR will be somethin even better - my fault - felt for marketing tricks of Oculus.I was disappointed:- no antialiasing, object in distance look horrible- blurred on edges- constant motion sickness (might be due to my IPD which is 68)- Oculus software crashing quite often- some of the offered games are poorly optimized for VR and therefore low FPS regardless of your PC specification- feels like a horrible downgrade in graphics after using good quality monitorIt's a bit of a lottery how your eyes will perceive this - some love it , some hate it and some get motion sickness.Just be aware of this when buying this headset - RESERCH WHAT TO EXPECT.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 September 2019
review_title: Dont get to exited when getting this item.

one_reviews_text: i feel like i wasted my money!im close to tears at this point.i set it all up and it worked it felt so good, but then i noticed something and it was shattered for me...i can see dots (like the pixels) on the screen.im hoping (in a way) that its my underpowered cpu/gpu (they are both from 2017 i5, and a nvidea gpu thats also 2017 or older.its just the dots, it works perfectly other than that, the gaurdian mode is excellent.the tracking seemed amazing (new user)but the dots and insane lag broke it fore me :(i just want head-pats from my friends in vr chat :( (yes i know that app has its own problems, but its not that, the issue occurs for me across all apps even the oculus set up ones! which are cute btw!)
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 8 August 2020

one_reviews_text: Shame it just don't work when try to play games via steam goes black screen a static crash then loses the tracking of the controls causing me to have to restart and try and try again. Usb 3 plug in correct updated usb drivers. Display port plugged into a rtx 2080ti proceccesor i7 8700k so should be more the compatible to be working maybe a got a dud one ?
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 24 November 2020

one_reviews_text: Just no... Yes, it is VR. Yes, you can experience it. No, it won't be for everyday fun.Owned by FB. All you need to know. Honestly, it's okay if you have loads of spare money and a lot of time fixing it, but logically it's just not worth it.With EVERY tiny Windows update it will crash. Then you will play at least few hours trying to fix it. It even migh kill your windows. Then passive processes. You don't use VR at the time, no worries, processes will still drain your resources like 2 extra antiviruses.Honestly, even that it was fun to experience VR for the first time, Oculus doesn't have a lot to offer so you would enjoy it longer than a month. And all those side effects...it's just not worth it. I consider it my worst purchase I have made in last decade.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 1 September 2021

one_reviews_text: As the title says, this is an improvement over the original Rift. Image quality is crisp, reading in VR easier and I personally like the the PSVR style headset and the sensors are better. I also like the addition of being able to see the real world at the double tap of a button, for those moments when you want to reorient yourself. However they removed the headphones, which I liked. Don't get me wrong I can understand their thinking to a point, allowing you to hear both VR and real world does have its benefits, but it destroys immersion. (You can plug in your own earphones/headphones) And just like the original, it has its quirks. Like the right controller refusing to sync during setup, until you've tried several times. And for those getting the Driver update loop. It's easily fixed if you unplug your headset completely. Then plug in usb first until headset light goes white then plug in Displayport. By doing this, I no longer have any issues with it. When not in use, it's unplugged. Like I said flawed, but VR can be so immersive and fun that to a point I can ignore the quirks and enjoy the experience.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 7 February 2020
review_title: An improvement of the original, but flawed
