one_reviews_text: So i have had the Rift S for 10 weeks, downloaded and installed all the firmware updates, uninstalled and reinstalled Oculus software a few times and still today the tracking froze again fpr the 80th time probably, DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT IT DOESN'T WORK!!After 10 weeks of all the updates and trying everything it still doesn't work, Oculus have released a faulty product!!Ok i'v added 2 stars because Oculus seem to have ironed out all the problems associated with the launch and well after, i would recommend buying it now in it;s current state.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 August 2019

one_reviews_text: I've owed the CV1 and I have to say yes it's a upgrade screen and lens but everything else is terrible.I had to send this back same day because, even though I've owed a CV1 the original DK1 and VIVE I've never once felt sick or dizzy. Not even after hours and hours of gameplay on crazy fast games.Within a few min of this RIFT S I was dizzy and sick. The headset has no manual IPD adjuster. It's done in software and honestly it makes no difference changing it.The image is super sharp and crisp bigger sweet spot no screen door and God rays next to none, but for me it's completely unusable. And had to go back. I'm thinking of getting the quest instead now. As it has manual IPD and soon will be able to play all rift and steam games with oculus link.And let's not talk about the audio. What a waste of time it is. It's pathetic. They shouldn't of done it and just give some earbubs to plug in in the package. It's really bad. Tinny no bass and about 30% of the volume of the rift. It's bad.Anyway. If they used the headstrap and audio of the CV1 with adjustable IPD with the rift s lens and screens it would of been perfect.Sadly I've sent it back.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 October 2019
review_title: Had to send back. Made me ill and dizzy. And that's never happened on any other headset.

one_reviews_text: Impossible to use - you get it set up and play for a bit, return the next day and it says software reboot required, after doing all of that the unit never came online. Had to unplug and plug the headset back again (first the display and then usb, otherwise does not work) to use it. Sometimes it will stop working mid game. Thanks Oculus for charging for a test unit.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 7 September 2019

one_reviews_text: I got this because it's an inside out system (no lighthouses) that's easy to set up. I had a problem at first when my comp crashed during a firmware update, afterwards it wouldn't detect the dp connection. I downloaded reinstalled and no joy, I skipped instalation and the oculus app had detected my rift s and asked me to update the firmware again. I did so without any mishaps and I was away. So even with a bit of ball ache it was less than an hour and I was away.When I first put it on (this is my first VR experience) I was taken back by the sense of depth and spacial awareness. I originaly got this for the head tracking in flight simulators but it's much more than that. I went through the training for Star Trek: Bridge Crew, an intensely tedious task on my pc+monitor but on the oculus it was awesome, and that's not an overstatement. Also the Rift S was detected by Steam VR and set up without a hitch.In short, for the £350 I paid this is well worth it, pc gaming just went to a whole new level. Are there better VR headsets out there? Sure, but as far as bang for your buck goes it's Oculus Rift S for me.EDIT: I starting getting a problem where my controllers freeze in mid air every 5-30 minutes, they retained roll and pitch but lost full 6DOF. I jumped through hoops but finally solved the problem by purchasing a powered USB hub from amazon. It's also possible to solve the problem by unplugging my mouse and headset but the usb hub causes less trouble, aside from that the Rift S is holding up perfectly. Nearly a month later I'm still happy with my purchase.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 29 November 2019

one_reviews_text: Je viens du WMR de première génération, et pour moi ce casque est pratiquement une révélation.Je ne nie pas quelques défauts, mais dans l'ensemble, tout est très bon, très peaufiné et très cohérent. Vous branchez votre casque, vous lancez votre jeu (même Steam) et c'est tout. Tous les réglages se font facilement une fois le casque enfilé, à travers des menus très lisibles et très clairs, et toujours immédiatement accessibles, même en jeu. Les allers-retours entre le jeu et le mode de configuration sont aisés, même si pas forcément parfaits pour des jeux Steam; mais c'est bien plus confortable que tout ce que j'ai pu voir à ce jour.Je trouve le casque un peu cher à 450 euros, mais il n'y a rien d'équivalent dans cette gamme de prix (Vive à plus de 1000 euros). L'avantage, c'est que la résolution du casque, suffisante mais modérée, convient à des PCs de jeu qui ne coûtent pas une fortune. Venant du WMR, je ne trouve pas la perte de résolution très génante, même si elle se voit à l'écran. Au contraire, la dalle est d'une qualité très supérieure (colorimétrie, contraste), et çaredonne vie à des tableaux bien ternes sur WMR. Et surtout, la dalle est nette: on peut très facilement utiliser le bureau windows tellement les textes, mêmes petits, restent lisibles. J'insiste: c'est très utilisable...Après plusieurs dizaines d'heures de jeu, je pense que la qualité d'image est largement à la hauteur de la plupart des jeux, et en particulier les jeux où ça bouge! La réactivité du casque et des manettes devient aussi importante que la qualité d'image, plus que la résolution en tous cas, et de ce point de vue le casque est nettement supérieur à tous les WMR. Il y a notamment une MAJ firmware qui date du 23/07 qui améliore nettement le suivi des manettes.Le sens du détail technique et logiciel est impressionnant, et ça se retrouve dans l'ergonomie à tous points de vue. Sans être exempt de défauts, et sans être aussi peaufiné et bien fini que l'était le CV1 (aux dires de leurs possesseurs), ce casque est TRES performant, très équilibré et très bien fini. Skyrim VR devient un jeu quasi-parfait, capable de vous voler encore une centaine d'heures!Qualités:* finitions générales impressionnantes* support natif de l'Oculus Store (émulé par Revive pour les autres, avec des dégâts parfois)* support natif de tous mes jeux VR dispo sur Steam* support de Revive ( abonnement à 15€/mois pour une centaine de jeux VR au moins, 15 j d'essai gratuit)* visuels nets, colorés, vifs* optiques excellentes, sweet spot extrêmement généreux, réglage de la profondeur facile* réglage de la zone de jeu se fait directement en mode vidéo, le casque se souvient du réglage sans décalage* passage facile du mode jeu au mode paramètres, avec accès à la vidéo de votre aire de jeu, à la reconfiguration facile de la direction initiale* l'avertissement visuel de proximité de murs ne ruine pas la qualité visuelle* bureau windows utilisable facilement et lisiblement.* manettes légères (une pile seulement), consomment peu, suivi excellent* casque confortable, ergonome, adapté aux petites et aux grosses têtes* chauffe très très peu, mais un peu quand-mêmeQuelques défauts. Je ne veux pas 'casser' le casque, chacun a ses défauts, mais voici ceux que j'ai notés ici:* j'aurais aimé pouvoir éteindre complètement le casque sans le débrancher* le casque devient par défaut la sortie audio de windows; pourtant, pour certains jeux Steam, il est nécessaire d'aller sur SteamVR pour définir le Rift S comme sortie audio (une fois pour toutes heureusement).* réglage d'IPD logiciel seulement, comme sur presque tous les WMR. Mais le Quest et le Vive ont un réglage manuel.* il faut acheter un cable doubleur d'alimentation USB. Ca vaut pour tous les casques, surtout les WMR. Sinon, risque d'écran noir, qui demande de rebrancher le casque.* il faut acheter des piles rechargeables quand-même* c'est mieux d'acheter une boite pour le protéger de la poussière et de la lumière (écrans sensibles aus UV)* ce casque a une dalle LCD, comme presque tous les casques de cette génération. Or, sur le Quest, ou sur les Rift et Vive d'ancienne génération, on avait du OLED. Le LCD présente énormément d'avantages (pas de grille notamment), mais il y a un inconvénient: le mauvais rendu des scènes obscures. Dès qu'un niveau est *très* sombre, la luminosité résiduelle de la dalle va rendre des scènes peu lisibles. On s'en rend compte dans pas mal de scènes de Vader Immortal, prévu pour OLED. En général, ça ne pose *aucun* problème pour la plupart des jeux (Skyrim VR), mais Karnage Chronicles souffre pas mal je trouve.* le cable est un peu trop rigide, et il a tendance à conserver une torsion résiduelle. C'est décevant à ce niveau de prix. Heureusement, on trouve des suspenseurs de cable à 20 euros qui aident énormément. Perso, j'ai pu les fixer sur des meubles ou des parties en PVC de mon salon, sans avoir à percer aucun trou.* Il ne semble pas facile ni possible de changer la mousse faciale, qui absorbe toute votre sueur. C'est dommage si on veut faire essayer le casque à des gens. A noter que même sur les casques où toutes les mousses sont amovibles, toutes ne sont pas en vente.* l'audio par défaut est correct, avec des hauts-parleurs acceptables intégrés dans le casque, de même qu'un bon micro. Par contre, s'il y a du bruit ambiant ou si on veut une bonne qualité d'écoute, il faut ajouter des écouteurs classiques qui se branchent sur le casque. Je regrette les écouteurs de qualité qu'on trouvait sur l'ancien Rift ou sur le Vive actuel.* le compartiment à piles a tendance à s'ouvrir quand on smashe avec la manette; mais par chance il se remet tout seul (rail, aimant: top finition quand-même).Au final, les divers problèmes sont notables, mais l'impression générale est très bonne et très favorable à ce casque. Ce casque piétine les WMR de première génération, littéralement, et les rend désormais inutiles (sauf Samsung Odyssey). Ce casque résoud enfin les problèmes de résolution des Rift / Vive de génération précédente, et offre une image superbe, une ergonomie générale excellente, et une facilité d'utilisation et d'adaptation bluffantes. Tu branches, tu l'enfiles et tu joues de suite, sans voir ni sentir de défaut gênant.Dans cette gamme de prix, il était difficile de faire aussi bien. Car avec les technos VR, tout confort est question du prix qu'on est prêt à y mettre, et j'estime que les compromis qui ont été réalisés ici sont des plus pertinents. C'est bien simple: son seul concurrent direct est l'Oculus Quest avec ses jeux peu nombreux et chers.
review_date: Reviewed in France on 5 July 2019
review_title: Une vraie tuerie; pas parfait, mais inespérément bon dans cette gamme de prix

one_reviews_text: A lot of negatives in reviews.Firstly this connects to a gameport now. Hdmi is 60fps max.. Gameport smashes that with easily over 90fps on my system. I was an owner of the first oculus rift. Check my review. I sold that because it was so annoying with blank headset, nausea and so many wires and sensors. Rift s was so easy to set up and now works perfectly Well with steam stores games and oculus.  Yes it's cheaper quality build but still very well made and durable. Full support for xbox cobtroller. The speakers are weak but g ey plug in Bluetooth headset or a normal pair headphones. My lady session was over 3 hours and I actually forgot I was doing vr. No eye strain. This is still not perfect and you do get a bit of binocular vision. In dark areas you see the circles in the lenses. But mainly its an amazing experience.  ONE WIRE ONLY FROM Headset. Now you can plug and play. Take it to a friend's house. The controllers are bit smaller and I do wonder if the originals would work with rift s.  For £400 your getti g a heap of fun.  I enjoy watching YouTube on my virtual cinema screen. I prefer the reduction in build quality when like now the system is lighter and has better functionality. It works out of the box.One negative that I can't seem to fix is it wants me to find the floor and draw safety zone each time.  Sure its a security setting on my pc that needs a tweek. I can live with this. A very small problem
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 14 September 2020
review_title: Price and quality perfect balance for the performance

one_reviews_text: I find the people who complain about the Quest online are VR snobs and/or spent thousands on full body to be the 1% of VR users and are now being joined by people who spent far less (none body) thanks to Oculus. What they don't understand is that with a big user base come better games and a healthy market that benefits them.At first i was happy with Quest LINK but the battery slowly loses charge even when connected to the PC. I also know that batteries get worse over time (it needs a replaceable battery). So i decided to get the Rift S to solve this problem. The LCD on Rift S has less of a screen door effect to the Quest (only slightly) the trade off being the black levels not being deep black. I think am happy with this trade off. The Rift S is way more comfortable and the Quest should of had this design as it does not hinder the portability at all and is comfortable.My small gripes with the headset are.- I can't find the stationary circle guardian that the Quest has on the Rift S.- IPD is fixed 64.5 the software makes no difference. On the Quest am 62 but i find the fixed IPD on Rift S OK to use.- The cable needs another hook to support it (i think this is why people are complaining of blank screens i used velcro to fix it).- NO mechanical on/off button!!! I know this a contested issue and the solution is to unplug the USB. But leaving it plugged in i can't seem to get it to go into standby mode the screen turns off but not the controllers. And a white light stays on no matter how long i leave it.I get this strange smudge effect in VR on my RTX 2060 Super. It's not screen tear it's like a glitch but happens in all games and mainly happens in low frame rates. For example if i move my hand fast in front of me when it's happening my fingers stretch and smudge out. I thought this was a Quest LINK issue but i also get it on the Rift S. Does anyone else have this problem? Google comes up with nothing.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 31 December 2019
review_title: I own the Quest and Rift S (NO mechanical on/off button!)

one_reviews_text: This was the present my son really wanted. Opened the box.. all there. Then tried to connect it up to the Pc.Turns out my son’s Pc?which is only a year old, doesn’t have the right input socket. It has an HDMI socket and it needs a socket called Display port. There are adapters you can buy but the Rift S doesn’t support them.I checked the original listing and it does not make it clear that it doesn’t support HDMI. It really should especially since the previous rift did.I have 2 options.  Get a refund or spring for a new graphics card. Neither very palatable.The low score is not a reflection on the product it self as we haven’t got it connected. However, not every parent is aware of all the different ports. HDMI is the one port every body understands and if we can’t use it this needs to be made clear.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 25 December 2020

one_reviews_text: As an original rift owner, I have mixed feelings about the Rift S. The image quality is better than the CV1. The resolution is higher, the sweet spot is larger and the god rays have been almost completely removed. The colours are more muted, which I didn't like, but YMMV. I also wasn't keen on the 10FPS drop which I found noticeable, if not a deal breaker. The lack of an analogue IPD adjuster could be a problem for some, but it was fine for me.The whole thing is much easier to set up and adjust for different users and the foam used on the facial interface is far less prone to both causing and soaking up sweat, but it's less comfortable to wear for long periods and seems to move around more during play.The in-built audio is poor. It's tinny and lacks any semblance of bass, plus it's quiet enough - even at 100% - to allow you to hear background noise.The controllers feel cheap, the haptic feedback is low and I found that I kept accidentally sliding the battery compartment open while playing Beat Saber, but the tracking seems mostly fine contrary to many things I'd heard.If you're going to buy the Rift S as an entry into the VR market, then you'll probably be happy, but if you own a Rift CV1 or a Vive then you're going to have to make compromises for that better image quality.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 24 September 2019
review_title: Good as an entry into VR, OK for everyone else.

one_reviews_text: The headset looks well made and is comfortable. Sadly it lacks sufficient adjustability for the lenses and I wasn’t able to find a sweet spot where it wasn’t blurry. The screens are not of a high enough resolution so it made things feel a bit “arcade-like”.Setup requires you to create a Facebook account. I created a bogus one since I don’t want to be on Facebook. Further, I didn’t want to use the Oculus software - I wanted to use it with my existing games in Steam. I did get this set up, but I expect some would struggle.I used the headset with Microsoft Flight Simulator and Assetto Corsa. Both gave me severe motion sickness in very short order. I don’t know if this was due to the lack of adjustability or if I’m just prone to it.I’m sure many people enjoy this for VR games, but it’s just not good enough for sims. You may find the motion sickness affects you too. I had to return it as it was unusable for me.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 3 March 2021

one_reviews_text: Right. Where to begin. There are things that don't make sense with this. To get it to work I had to manually install steam VR. Then it worked with Windows mixed reality games, But not the mixed reality portal. That aside, on a 1660ti laptop it runs amazing. Ms flight sim 2020 on vr is mind blowing. I know I'm asking my laptop to perform miracles, but clever frame simulation means even a rubbish 10 fps on flight sim is playable on vr. It guesses the next frame and makes it feal like 30 fps. There are weird glitches but that's to be expected with ms flight sim still not fully optimised for cpus or vr. Other games run smooth and the pass through is fun in its own right seeing all things infrared. Flashy TV remote was quite a lol. I gave 5 stars as I was astounded at how far vr has come. But there are things to be aware of. It's hard to set up and a pain to run. Plus motion sickness is a real possibility. You get used to the tracking, but anything low frame rate like flight sim and it can make you feel like you're in a blender. I feel off for about an hour after too so plan ahead if you got to drive anywhere later! Now if I could just get an rtx3090 to go with it..... Hmmmm
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 18 January 2021
review_title: Getting to work is a challenge. Once it works its fantastic!

one_reviews_text: I gave them 5 stars as the kit is pretty good, I was impressed with the demo and some games I played with them, but in just a month they found there way into a draw and have stayed there ever since. I don't regret buying them, but they were clearly a waste of cash. The reason they ended up in the draw is mainly because they make me sick if there is any sort of movement in the game, my uncle has a set and he has the same problem, my son tried them and had no issues, so I think they are probably ok on younger people, but maybe no so much for older (40 +). The other thing with them is that they are kind of a gizmo, not really functional, most games don't really work very well with them. If you have the cash to spare and just want to try out something new, I highly recommend trying it out, but if cash is a bit tight, Id recommend maybe giving this a swerve for a few years.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 16 February 2021

one_reviews_text: Can’t really say how good it was as it wouldn’t ever connect to any of my pcs and they all had above spec.I believe it was to do with usb incompatibility on oculus end as I found a load on the net about it.Amazon were very good and refunded me straight away so I got a quest 2 and now use it via link cable (anker powerline) for pc vr.If I was you I’d avoid this as the quest 2 can do the same job via virtual desktop or via link cable and also be used as a standalone headset without pc.no brainier to me but everyone if different. Either way enjoy man vr is cool
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 19 January 2021
review_title: Seemed good but wouldn’t work for me no matter what I did

one_reviews_text: Over the 10 month, I had various things go wrong with, I've spent hundreds trying to make the experience better,  by having to get a better mic because the mic is bad, but still that didn't fix the sound which is crackling. To external usb hubs to controller covers and face covers - The tracking went bad, then it started crashing, first once a month then up to once every 2 mins, after weeks of trying to problem-solve with Oculus they requested it back I'm now almost 3 weeks without a VR and no replacement as they promised I would get after 3-5 day and no refund.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 November 2020

one_reviews_text: When im in game or even in the home screen, 5 minutes after putting it on, sensors stops working and if i enter passtrough mode, i see tv snowflakes. I searched on the internet for more than 5 hours and there is no solution at all. Extremely disatisfied. Do not buy.
review_date: Reviewed in Canada on 8 June 2019

one_reviews_text: I wish I could rave about the Rift S, it has some great pros and made some good memories, it was the better choice for a very long time compared to other headsets. I even did extensive research before buying one of my own so it was clearly a commitment for me, sadly that commitment has come to a bitter end.The best pro for me are the controllers, they never failed me once and they are my favourite to use out of all the ones I've used.Please note however, these following issues aren't exclusive to me, but I've seen so many reports, forums and personal interactions of these same issues with other people.Well kept and cared for, the headset could be used for hours on end for months with no issue, but eventually my games started to crash, I brushed it off as just game bugs or temporary issues, however, after 1 year of owning it I know now it's 100% the Oculus itself, perhaps even just Oculus's client. Those crashes have turned into a daily occurrence to the point of me just simply not using the headset, I literally can't, 2 minutes into ANY game I can guarantee a crash.Screen flashes, freezing, the microphone was buggy from day 1 by the way.. and the built in headphones stopped working about 8 months in but I used my own headphones anyway.This is NOT a result of my system, it is the same on my PC, my parents, my laptop and my friends PC. I tried absolutely everything you can imagine. From every driver, to clean installs of anything related and even Windows.I don't think I've missed anything but comment if you need more detail, just please maybe find a different brand, I'm personally going to make my next purchase a Vive or Index. (For casual gamers around this price range, the Quest 2 just came out but always do your research.)P.S My attached video is what my monitor sees when a crash happens, inside the headset is complete stuttering and static image on every system I've experienced this on. Rebooting the game gives me nothing but static and no headset picking up. PC needs to be restarted every time.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 17 October 2020
review_title: One of my most disappointing purchases

one_reviews_text: Went for this as it was cheaper than the quest 2 at the time of buying (July 2021) and it blew me away, everything feels so real once its one and comfort isn't an issue either so you could wear this for 5+ hours without any breaks! Controllers are amazing too and at this price range are the best you can get compared to the new controllers the quest 2 have!My only complaint which is an easy fix is the guardian keeps resetting when the lighting changes daylight and a light at night but guardian can be turned off in settings to stop that :)UPDATE 6 months later: Down to 2 stars from 5.So the headset it still great but a few things have happened.The display cable clip on the halo has snapped off, i keep getting "your display cable isn't connected" every now and then, the left controller has a slight separation near the top trigger and the front of the ring on the right controller has cracked in half. I sit down most of the time and have only dropped the controllers a few times from my desk and lap so the durability hasn't been the best but hopefully it could just be due to me getting a bad or faulty one and would normally be fine for other people. I would recommend going for a quest 2 though at this point since the headset isnt being sold anymore and I was lucky to get one brand new.I will be moving on to the valve index next month anyway but this has been a great headset to start with and see if I liked VR, just wish I went with the quest 2 instead.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 14 August 2021

one_reviews_text: Let's start with the biggest issue.The headband is easily removable, however forehead and back head bands are not. Those are very tricky to remove, and probably can break after 3-5 attempt.Why is this important ?- HYGIENE !!! You have to wash them up every 2-3 weeks depending on the usage (the thing is getting hot and most of people can get sweaty especially with movement).This oculus was never designed to last > 6 months. You cannot replace and easily clean all the parts. The sweat might also get to the PCB under the lens (found some reviews about that, as headband / rubber around lenses, is not water proof, if you will put down the oculus on the front plate, you risk moisture to get into inside after while).Usability:- You cannot adjust lenses, what a terrible idea, wasn't a big issue, but I've felt like a big downgrade from oculus cv1.- cable is attached to the side, which it makes very uncomfortable (it should be attached to the back so cable could go down along with your spine, don't know how many time I would trip)- Good thing is that the set won't fog anymore (in comparison to CV1)- Great tracking without external sensors (really liked it).Visual quality:- Yes, quality is better than CV1 (in terms of screen door effect), however refresh is low.A bit hard decision, as if they would make all bands replaceable (magnets) in a way that you can throw them into the laundry machine, maybe I would be able to overlook some of the issues.Overall I would say it was a step-back as if I cannot use it for more than 3 weeks, then nothing else matter.Also the headband material around your eyes is terrible, pretty much cheapest possible material that maybe you could find at some $3 flight cases, definitely not something that should touch your skin. Horrrrrible material.Added a start due to better video quality & SDE & tracking without external sensors.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 9 November 2019
review_title: Better visual quality, much worse usability. Lack of hygiene.

one_reviews_text: First time Vr gaming headset user,The GOOD stuff ,easy to unbox the headset and to plug in fell good sturdy polished product,easy to download the software,easy to set up,very good tutorial,easy to find games or other content in oculus shop,you can find some nice free stuff ,to bad there are no demos for games,i have tried a few games and most are boring just move around sometimes you interact with something,some are difficult to adjust to the camera movement make me fell sick,played a action game and i got tired of shooting arrows or fireballs it was a surprise!!!you need to be in good shape!best game i played  was beat saber 40 hours or so make you sweat but no sickness,Now the Bad stuff,for me USB connection is a constant problem ,i have to remove and plug in the usb every time the headset is idle for more than 10 min,i have tried all my USB ports 3.0-3.1-2.0 all the same,sometimes the guardian FIELD just resets and i have to do the setup again,after you exit oculus the headset and controllers stay ON and drain battery fast! only if u unplug USB again!,headset its light but because you are not used to have weight on your head you will feel muscle pain in you neck and sholders,3 weeks and i can still fell it.and last thing if are more users adjusting the headset with long hair or ponytail it can take some time.OK- overall its Ok you can have lots of fun,if you are getting sick at first  you can change the game or app but in tine you can get used to.i hope i can find more thing to have more use of it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 18 March 2021

one_reviews_text: I'm impressed it's simplicity and the robustness.Setup was super simple, and the inside out tracking works really well - no tracking issues for me, even with games like beat Sabre. It's indistinguishable from tracking with beacons.I've seen some complaints about software, but it's been rock solid while I've been using it.I assume the software has improved over time?One flaw this headset does have is the fact that the pads on the mask are not replaceable, and might soak up sweat long term - maybe consider getting after market sleeves to put on top of the padding for hygiene.It's a close battle between this headset and the Oculus Quest (as the quest will be receiving 'Oculus Link' in Nov 2019 which allows it to be tethered to a PC) but I think this wins out if you're only planning to play games while tethered - It's lighter, more comfortable, and I think the slightly lower resolution screen is a good tradeoff for a higher refresh rate and higher FOV.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 September 2019

one_reviews_text: this is a great vr headset. do not believe the negative reviews on the internet there is nothing wrong with this vr hmd. the built in sound quality is great. the display quality is 100% better than the HTC Vive as a previous owner. build quality is great.  easy to install and get going than the Vive. there are no circular rays at all on the lens in vr. can play all steam vr games straight from the steam desktop. no button mapping needed. like i said don't believe the negative reviews on the net. the ipd is not an issue with me since the playstation vr does not have on aswell and I've been using that for over 2 years.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 1 November 2019
review_title: great vr headset. don't believe the negative reviews on the net.

one_reviews_text: Having bought the Oculus Go I decided to go the whole hog and buy the rift S wanting the full computer VR gaming experience and I'm so pleased I did it!! Straight out of the box you download the app from the Oculus web site which does everything for you, step by step it tells you everything you need to do to get going. After installing you get a few free apps to show you the way and after searching the web a little I found top VR games at very low prices. Only owning it for a few days I'm still trying to get to grips with everything especially the controllers which are very alien to me but with a little practice I'm sure I'll get used to them. All in all it's very impressive and I'm looking forward to a VR future!!!!!
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 5 November 2019

one_reviews_text: It's such a shame, this headset when everything is working is fantastic. Unfortunately it's let down by catastrophic software/device driver failures.I returned mine after about a week of it deciding repeatedly not to work after either I took the headset off my head or rebooting my PC.Everytime it decided it wanted to work it was FLAWLESS ! Tracking was spot on, image quality was great, even the audio was ok (not great) but I still enjoyed playing VRCHAT, Vader Immortal and Blade and Sorcery with no issues.Issues only arose when I took it off or turned off my pc. When I tried again the headset would either appear to be connecting and disconnecting itself repeatedly, give a black screen with the orange dot LED or show 3 dots on a black screen indefinitely.I was using the USB 3 PCI card recommended by Occulus:Inateck Superspeed 4 Ports PCI-E KT4001I tried it with the latest Inateck drivers, which don't work with the RIFT S drivers. It gives code 31 in device manager (Unable to load drivers ) and a yellow warning triangle. So you have to manually use the Microsoft USB Hub drivers in the device manger for the 2 x RIFT S devices.Device Manager > Universal Serial Bus Controlers > Update Drivers > Browse My Computer for Drivers > Let me pick from a list > Then select the Default one listedWorked fine for a couple of days then the issues above started. There was no change to Hardware/Software or updates. Pc was shut down and I tried it the next day and the issues started.So I tried different USB 3 ports on the card. Same issues. Reboot repeatedly. Unplug/plug back in. Checked the Camera privacy settings were ON. Tried all combinations of USB legacy/handover settings in BIOS. Made sure Nvidia drivers were up to date and overlay/shadowplay was disabled. Made sure power management on all the USB devices had the option to allow the PC to turn off the device to save power disabled. Enabled/Disabled Beta software/drivers in Occulus software. Reinstalled Oculus software.Then I got it to work by changing the drivers in the device manager again:Inateck USB 3.0 Card - Fresco Logic xHCI (USB3) Controller FL1100 Series > USB xHCI Compliant Host ControllerRift S devices x 2 - xHCI Hub > Rift SSo this time it worked with the USB 3.0 card using default Microsoft drivers and the Rift S using its Occulus drivers.Worked fine for an evening with NO issues during gameplay. But as soon as I shut down and started it up again, the same issues started. Kept disconnecting and reconnecting itself. Black screen with orange led or the 3 dots that just stay there.This time none of the aforementioned driver settings worked. The device just kept connecting and disconnecting itself. I don't think it's a cable issue otherwise it would've stopped working mid-game in the 14+ hours I got out of it. It just seems to not want to work for a few hours and then decides to start working (at least until you take it off or turn off your pc).I think if they got the drivers to work then Oculus would take over the market because it's cheap and works damn well when you can get the driver/software stars to align. Such a shame.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 31 December 2019
review_title: Amazing WHEN it works... Oculus you need to sort out your drivers/software

one_reviews_text: Was a little worried about software only IPD adjustment but hasn't been an issue.Followed another reviews advice to change USB link state to turn off power saving and have had zero issues with static or black screen.Running on a i5 2600 with a gtx 1070 and it runs great. The kids are allowed limited time on it but are constantly asking to have a go. I have used it for brass tactics,  Arizona sunshine, lost echo, super hot and a few other free titles and it is amazing and immersive.The halo band and lenses slider make it easy to adjust. It is reasonably comfortable, not too heavy. The built in speakers work fine but can use your own noise cancelling ones for total immersion.Controllers are decent and feel good in the hand, have seen some complain that the magnetic battery cover can come off during play but I have not had that issue.The inside out tracking works great and removes a ton of hassle using satellite camera for trackingYou have to sign up to a Facebook style account but don't need to use Facebook and you can turn off all online sharing if like me you can't stand social media.In all for a gaming vr headset it's just at the point of affordable and it works as intended. Is great fun to play and lowers the barrier to entry. Highly recommend!
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 January 2020

one_reviews_text: as everything with that zuckerberg GIT do not buy this (depending on your morals/paranoia/etc) It is from the guy who OWNS facebook and sold all our info and went to court about it....It FORCES you to use facebook to sign in and if you refuse to have a facebook account it will be considered an *ornament/brick*If you can get beyond this and have the money then the games .... SOME of them... are amazing...But with occulus being shut down these are being *filtered out* ... will we ever get another VR company doing these headsets (generally speaking???)I refuse to buy any other model (quest/go/etc) because they are NOT as good as Rift S (personal opinion, but many hate it) also you cant buy from Amazon anymore this unit
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 28 August 2021

one_reviews_text: I have now used the Oculus Rift S for about a year now and feel that I can put a fair and decently structured review of this product and we will start off with the design...So the design of this headset is very simple but gets the job done, sleek and robust in structure... However, it's pretty front heavy, it has issues with heat and trying to melt your face, the plastic is cheap, the foam padding to protect your face from the plastic falls apart after some use (the foams protective fabric fell off after 3 weeks of use for me but may vary on how much the headset is used) and the plastic clip that is meant to protect your display wires from pinching snaps way too easily which then leaves the wire dangling procariously and risking damage to said wire or the headsets display point.Then we have the Oculus Touch controllers, they are light and pretty easy to get a handle on using except they have an issue with controller drift, pretty bad controller drift for that as dust and other gunk can get under the stick and mess with the censor, even with constant cleaning like I did.Next we will talk about the software, Oculus uses it's own system called well... "Oculus" this has to be installed to your C: drive and is 15gb~ to install (before driver updates), once you have all that installed you must merge a facebook account too the app in order to use the device plus it seems to not really allow people to create new accounts and just add them to the app it has to be an older account but I cannot confirm this as I used my main account i had for 11 years, once all that is done you go through ur unskippable health and safety video which isn't much an issue and after all that, a small vr tutorial and ur free to play as you please, but be very wary of driver updates for your graphics card as the headset has a tendency to brick your graphics card if it is plugged in while you update it, this can only be fixxed by uninstalling and reinstalling the graphics card through your device manager on ur pc and also I have a issue currently where the vr is operating fine but refuses to detect the tracking (no idea how to repair this yet) which makes play on the headset impossible as it will not even bother loading you into the vr space.If you are wanting to use your steam games and account (just like 90% of the playerbase does) then you must stress your PC or Laptop more by running both Oculus and SteamVR at the exact same time which is a horrific waste of pc resources and causes pretty bad performance issues if your device is lower end, Ovulus will also sometimes refuse to open SteamVR or even acknowledge that the program is open, what causes this I do not know but it can be pretty annoying as if it doesn't fix from closing and reopening SteamVR then you must unplug and replug in your headset which if your pc is in a difficult to reach spot like mine is it can be extremely annoying to deal with...The support... Oh no the support... Honestly you would get better support throwing a fish at a wall expecting it to fly... Though they do try their best they are just terrible at fixxing the issue and seem to have an issue when you try to use your warranty to repair things and trust me... You are going to be using that warranty for a few things as this headset seems to have a heavy track record of messing up quite spectacularly.In my conclussion to my experience to this headset, I would strongly suggest steering clear of this device and possibly the Quest though I cannot say anything for the Quest and spend the extra money on an index or a vive, they both also have problems but they are a million times better than this conpanies products are as far as I can currently gather.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 26 February 2022

one_reviews_text: Ok so I upgraded from the rift to the rift S and I have seen a big improvement in graphics. BUT!!The issue I have is when the Oculus make game exclusives for the Quest 2 and pass on the Rift and the Rift S they have completely bypassed pc VR and people who buy this item."The game is Star Wars Tales From The Galaxies Edge and Jurassic World Aftermath And the Climb 2 this makes the company look like game dev are not making a game for pc VRMy best advice is to wait to save up your money and get a quest 2 with a data cable so it can be plug directly into your pc so you can play any pc titles you will have the best of both markets, mobile VR and PC VR.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 March 2021

one_reviews_text: The specification under "is your PC Occulus ready" on Amazon states you need HDMI/(USB) 1.3 video output. This is the specification for the Occulus Rift NOT the Occulus Rift S.The VR set was unusable on Christmas day as not compatible with our PC. I spent 2 hours driving round on Boxing Day to try to get a compabile linking cable - which doesn't exist.We had bought (not refundable) digital games, so decided to change the graphics card (same spec, but WITH a Display port) - and Amazon were going to give us £70 towards the graphics card as the description is wrong on their website.The Oculus Quest was then reduced in price so we sent the Rift S back for a refund.We are no longer out of pocket, but I spent HOURS online/telphone with Amazon Customer Service who did not really understand the problemMore than a month later, the item is still badly described on the website - which is illegal.Son is more than happy with the Oculus Quest.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 January 2021

one_reviews_text: I loved this headset but it made me think my pc was the issue when it gave continuous USB connection issues.I followed hours of fixes online ranging from driver installations, software repairs, complete re-installs and so on.I had a GTX 1080 and a 5th Gen i7, 850 Watts PSUA few months later I built my current PC.GTX 308010th Gen i5Z490 MSI Mobo850W PSU32GB RAM 3600mhzThe issue persisted, so I replaced the headset with the same model as I thought the headset may be the problem.The Brand New Rift S had the exact same issue.If you check online for 'USB connection not working Rift S' you'll see hundreds and thousands of other users with this issue, over the past 2 YEARS. Oculus do not plan on fixing this.Invest in an Index from Valve if you have the money or maybe the Quest 2 but be aware that it's still Oculus, the same company who let the Rift  S die as they focuses solely on the Quest even if you did pay £400 for the Rift S.The Headset was amazing though, when it did manage to work the few times that it did it was a great experience. VR is one of the best gaming experiences I've had in a long time, definitely look into it but don't buy this specific Headset.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 February 2021
review_title: A Great Headset with Detrimental Software Issues

one_reviews_text: this headset is not for everyone. just got it today. setup didnt work well, the guardian system wasnt working correctly and everything was blurred, upon going into games, my controllers we not linking up properly either - only one shows. i also had random moments where the headset screen would go red. i also saw everything twice, then into further investigation noticed some of it was to do with my ipd. my ipd is 57, i didnt realise at first the ipd was only software adjustable. if you have an ideal ipd, buy this. if you dont, wait. trust me. ive saved money up for around 2 years to buy this (i was looking at other headsets) and am extremely disappointed. i also wear glasses which didnt fit the headset either. so this isnt suitable for glasses wearers unless you buy the lenses, which are around £60.also heard about the fact that you can now only use a rift s with a facebook account - so i stopped completely from this.tdlr; dont buy this unless u have lenses, an ideal ipd and an extra £100 to spend on third party accessoriesedit; i bought the quest 2 and its better - ipd is better range, wireless, better controllers etc. psvr or not, quest 2 is better
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 August 2020
review_title: trust me, DO NOT buy this - GET THE QUEST 2!

one_reviews_text: A diferencia de su predecesor, este headset es mucho más cómodo y fácil de configurar. Recuerda los cuartos en los que lo has jugado, así que solo es cuestión de conectarlo y jugar. Los controles se sienten muy cómodos, de igual forma. Tomen en cuenta que necesitan una pc o laptop que cuente con Display Port o Mini Display Port directo a la tarjeta gráfica, es indispensable pues no hay adaptador que funcione en este momento. La posibilidad de salir del juego y ver el mundo real con las cámaras integradas ayuda mucho en cuestión de seguridad y configuración.El software de oculus es el único contra que encuentro, pues depende de los servidores de Facebook y se cae más de lo aceptable. También a veces lanzan actualizaciones con bugs y puedes quedarte sin jugar algunas horas o días hasta que reparan la actualización.Fuera de eso, es un hardware muy bien hecho. Eso si, solo vale la pena la actualización desde el primer rift si quieres más comodidad y facilidad de instalación. Si estás bien con eso, entonces no hay problema.
review_date: Reviewed in Mexico on 12 July 2019
review_title: Excelente sistema, muy cómodo y fácil de instalar

one_reviews_text: I like it, I'll be honest there's an issue due to the USB connection not being recognised sometimes when you turn your PC on; when it does this you have to unplug it and plug it back in to make it work; it isn't ideal but doesn't mean its not a fantastic piece of hardware. FYI - if your headset isn't powered on due to the USB connection issue, it means your headset lenses may fog up; if you do the USB reconnection and leave it a few mins, your headset will warm up and prevent the fog build up.I use an i7 processor, 16gb RAM and a GTX1660ti gfx card and it runs like a dream. If you have the PC specs and you're looking to get into VR for the first time like I've done, then get this - if you haven't got a PC as powerful enough and want to get a VR, I would suggest getting the Oculus Quest 2 instead (but don't take my word for it, as I don't have one but having a top specced PC costs a bomb! so the next best thing :)
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 23 June 2021

one_reviews_text: This VR experience is amazing! When it works. It is very buggy, from the installer to the gameplay. It’s common for it to lose connection with your computer and require you to restart everything until it detects it, it’s common for tracking data to be lost on steam games and older games making 80% of the Experience bloody useless... don’t bother trying steam lab, completely unplayable.It’s also common for it to crash, to lag when tracking causing less response time, not in the footage that’s fine just in the headset itself which can cause a lot of motion sickness....The support is no good because it takes days for them just to get back to you. If you can afford it, get an index, if you can’t, wait! ... because there are far too many bugs right now to make it worth it.If you can only just afford the headset, also wait... it only comes with demos.... all the good games will cost you £20-£30 unless it’s on offer which is rare on the oculus store but very common for the steam storeWhen it works properly, it’s fast, smooth and responsive. It’s so immersive I’ve already jumping and hitting the roof, I’ve hit the wall on several occasions and I’ve had so much fun in general. It’s such a shame that it works less than half the time. If they can get updates to fix this then it will be totally worth the price
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 14 December 2019

one_reviews_text: It comes with everything you need right out of the box, has good quality to it and compared to the competition it's reasonably priced my only issue is I can't use it with my VR ready laptop as the rift s has a display port not a HDMI while my laptop only accepts HDMI, I bought a Displayport to HDMI adapter and it doesn't work so keep that in mind before you buy. I can use it with my computer at least
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 12 February 2020

one_reviews_text: Amazing just amazing. I waited years to have a go of a VR. As soon as opportunity came up to buy one I pounced. I was very worried if games out there be any good and I was worried about health and safety bits n pieces. Never had any issues with games or health things. I played ETS2 and it blew my mind on just how amazing this bit of kit was. The very next day I played Robo Recall and it was one mad but super fun game with excellent quality and graphics. I love love love my VR it helps me relax after a stressful day. There is so much choice of games as you have steam VR and Oculus Store too. So yea the oculus is gr8.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 29 October 2019

one_reviews_text: TL;DR - Headset is amazing, no real complaints with graphics or build quality. This headset is easily a must buy for beginners.I bought this headset as a first time VR user and I must say I was blown away.I was really nervous about buying it and putting it on just to see that everything was pixelated due to my eyes being so close to a screen (as it would with a monitor) although everything looks sleek and graphically amazing, I have no complaints when it comes to the quality of the graphics.The build quality of the headset is also great, nothing feels cheap or clunky, the controllers and the headset both feel pretty solid the only slight downside to the Rift S is that it isn't wireless although this is easily overcome by using a pulley system (not at all expensive) which I ended up buying within 1 day of owning the Rift S as the wires do get in the way.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 23 July 2021
review_title: Amazing for people looking to get into VR!

one_reviews_text: Dies ist das erste VR-Headset, das ich besitze und auch gleichzeitig mein erster VR-Kontakt/erste VR-Erfahrung.Die wenigen Teile in der Verpackung sind schnell ausgepackt und angeschlossen. Das Headset macht einen sehr kompakten und qualitativ wertigen Eindruck.Ich betreibe es mit einem I7 6700k und einer 1080 Grafikkarte. Bei einem "Querbeet"-Test durch verschiedenste Anwendungen/Games (u. a. Google Earth, lone echo, ISS Simulation, ...) brachte keines davon das Setup an Leistungsgrenzen. Das Headset ist sehr bequem und sehr schnell/einfach auf verschiedene Kopfformen einstellbar.Das "field of view" ist zwar nicht das von einer Pimax, aber es ist für mich ausreichend und nicht immersions-behindernd. Die fehlende mechanische IPD-Einstellung haben weder Kids noch Erwachsene vermisst. Der Sound ist ja im Vorfeld vielfach kritisiert worden und ich hatte entsprechend Schlimmes befürchtet. Die Beschränkung im Bassbereich ist definitiv da, allerdings ist der Sound ansonsten gut (klar und verzerrungsfrei).Die für mich persönlich einzige wesentliche Einschränkung sehe ich im Screendoor-Effekt, den ich als prominent wahrnehmbar empfinde. Nach etwas Eingewöhnung ist dieser aber akzeptabel und stört nicht.Unterm Strich halte ich das Headset gerade für VR-Newbies als perfektes Gerät. Mit dem guten Preis/Leistungsverhältnis der Rift S plus dem erweiterten Einsatzbereich bei der Quest hat Oculus viel für die Verbreitung von VR getan.
review_date: Reviewed in Germany on 22 May 2019

one_reviews_text: I was skeptical at first because of all the negative comments here. But my experience was flawless. Setup was very easy and fast. Played some games and watched movies no problems at all. Screen resolution is good enough for gaming etc.There are no external sensors which is good.. Also I like the design of new controllers. The only downside is sound .It is very weak.I had to use my own headphones.UPDATE : I am having white static flashes. I won`t change my review until it is fixed.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 25 June 2019

one_reviews_text: I have very mixed feelings about the rift S. When it works at its best it is a truly immersive experience, simple to get into and fantastic in execution. I have spent over 20 hours wandering around new worlds in No mans Sky feeling as though I could reach out and touch the world. But then come the problems with it losing all tracking. It seems on my unit the feeds from the cameras fail every so often and the only way to resolve is to power down the PC, Unplug the head set, restart the PC and reconnect. Not only tracking to pass though also goes down. This is happening about every 20 minutes now so 20 minutes of play, 10 minutes of messing around to get it back up and working, round and round we go. So while I really wanted to like the rift, today I have request a return and refund. While I am now a convert to VR I will wait to see what HTC is about to release and think about a Cosmos or Valve Index, or I may just give Oculus 6 months to sort out their QA and give the Rift another go.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 11 September 2019
review_title: Amazing when it works, frustrating when it does not

one_reviews_text: I've been using this headset for under two months and after the initial hurdles it gave me, I can finally say I love this product.Before I talk about my experiences I would like to highlight some important things you must keep in mind and some issues I initially faced. First off, after my first VR session I faced the issue of having to restart the oculus software before every session in order to temporarily fix a bug which was caused by my mobo USB ports not generating enough power. This was permanently fixed after I changed motherboard and reinstalled windows during my PC upgrade.Another issue you will likely face will be with the microphone of the Rift S, which in itself doesn't offer very good audio quality, but will likely either present you with phases of working normally to then sound like very cheap mic for a minute before it goes back to normal. I didn't experience this specific microphone problem, but mine just died on me after about 3 weeks. This promoted me to invest in a wireless ModMic which I attach to my bluetooth headset, and I'm very glad I decided to go with it.This was my first VR headset ever. I had never experienced VR before and the Rift S would be my ticket to the exciting world of VR. I didn't set my expectations too high but I was hyped. When I first hopped into VR, the Rift S worked out of the box after plugging it in and installing the desktop software. I was absolutely mesmerised and kinda just stood there looking around and throwing stuff in the tutorial area.After the tutorial and a few impressed family members, I decided to set up SteamVR and purchase Beat Saber. Beat Saber provided me with around 30 minutes of fun but really I was just trying to test it out. I then was invited to jump on VRChat with an irl friend who had been teasing me about it since like 2018. He showed me the ropes and I was hooked. Getting the Rift S was one of the best choices I have made, I must however admit that I only really use it for VRChat as it's helped me better my social skills and make new friends.The Rift S also works with the Vive trackers and base stations through SteamVR and space calibrator to offer full body tracking and I've had no issues with it so far. I can therefore recommend the Rift S for full body, although this is an expensive route.Overall, I can confidently say that I have no plans to upgrade from this headset to any more premium option like the index because I don't see the need to spend extra money when the Rift S is already a solid VR headset. You may ask, why do I give the Rift S a 5 star review after the issues it has? Because after I have resolved all the problems, I have now a very solid headset which provides me with everything I need to have a great VR experience.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 13 March 2021
review_title: The best VR headset if you have a PC, patience and prepared to spend money to buy a few extra pieces

one_reviews_text: Was tied between getting this or the Quest, with Oculus Link beta just being released. Decided to go with the Rift S, and was blown away with how good it actually is. Really easy to set up (ASUS 7170 Pro Gaming and Nvidea GTX 1060 6GB). Graphics are great and seems to be running smoothly so far. Massive step up from my PSVR.Only downside so far is that the battery covers do come off quite easily when playing fast paced games like Beat Saber.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 28 November 2019

one_reviews_text: Having read the reviews and from my own experience this either works well or is a constant cause of pain and anguish. The change to display port from HDMI makes most laptops difficult and Nvidia cards appear to add to this issue. I spent weeks trying to get this to work on a laptop with i7, 32 meg ram and 1060 nvidia graphics. Many games tell me i do not meet the required oculus specs but oculus website say i have above minimum requirements. The upto date graphic drivers simply do not work. My system will only work version 417.77. this appears to be stable but will not run all the games. Version 425.31 will run these games but keeps crashing. The support at oculus and nvidia have been next to useless. I would like to use oculus  but i would like to hear from somebody who has and is using it with no issues and what computer, plus specs they are running it on.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 January 2021
review_title: When it works Wow! But you must have the right system.

one_reviews_text: It's pretty good, especially for something that doesn't require base stations for tracking but the software to make it run is pretty bad: There aren't any good exclusives on it, the oculus VR space is awkward to move around and tends to make me feel more ill than the actual games, the compatibility to Steam is a bit dodgy (Can take up to 5 minutes to even enter the Steam VR Space), and it tells me that my headset audio apparently doesn't work but I resolve that by using a speaker. But that's pretty much the only thing I hate, the controls are pretty nice, the headset isn't too heavy although the adjustments could be a lot better, it's not too taxing on my PC and it looks great (although FOV feels really low and the only way to offset it is to don't think about it).Depending on your situation though, the Quest might be better suited for you since it doesn't require a PC and it's portable, the wires on the Rift S are quite annoying.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 27 February 2020
review_title: For what it is, it's excellent

one_reviews_text: This review is from someone who upgraded from the CV1 to the oculus rift s.If you haven't previous had a vr headset then get this. It's a great bit of kit and the setup is so simple.Now to all you people who are thinking about upgrading from the cv1  to the oculus rift s ....I dont have a designated VR area so if I want to play on the oculus I've previously had to set up the sensors everytime. This is where the S has brought back my love for vr. The external sensors on the headset have made the setup so simple that I literally just plug it into my PC, put the headset on and off I go! The screen resolution and clarity is obviously better than the cv1 and I can finally read text in the game with no issues and everything looks a lot cleaner. I've had no tracking issues. The only negatives are the black levels and audio. The only time I notice the black levels is in particularly dark scenes ( I just bought Vader immortals and when Vader is standing in front of you the blacks feel very grey ). This is only on a small amount of games and I haven't noticed it on most of the others I play. Now about the audio .... yes the bass is pretty bad. Playing beat saber is the only game I've noticed it being an issue. Every other game sounds great but obviously the sound will be missing the impact it previously had on the cv1. You can use your own headphones but I'm still confused as to why oculus chose this instead of the over ear headphone originally attached to the cv1. My last issue is the audio mirroring option has gone and just out putting through my PC speakers seems to give a slight delay which isnt good for games like beat saber.So my final conclusion is that the clarity of the screen does mostly outweigh the black issue. Audio is a problem but there's a work around but the big one for me is the ease of setup. I now play VR regularly and that would not be the case if I still had my cv1.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 25 June 2019
review_title: Great upgrade for anyone who doesnt want sensors

one_reviews_text: Having spent much time with the original Oculus rift, i can say without a shadow of a doubt that this is an upgrade, comfort is better, resolution is better, setup is a breeze and the pass through feature is brilliant. It's a fantastic introduction to vr as it isn't too expensive (relatively speaking) and gives you access to the oculus store and home, which in my opinion as well as the opinion of everyone else who's tried it, is far better than steam vr.My one major complaint is comfort, as a wearer of glasses it can get uncomfortable quickly, i have tried without glasses and it's not an issue, so i will be ordering custom prescription lenses for it, but i don't hold that against the headset, as for now i can remove the silicone nose rest part and it feels perfectly fine, still not amazingly comfortable but it's fine, obviously your mileage may vary but it is worth noting my glasses have rather think frames and dig into my nose after extensive periods of time, but again, i won't hold that against the headset.Overall, fantastic headset for a fantastic price with excellent games and experiences, just a little uncomfortable for extended use with glasses
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 November 2019

one_reviews_text: I was a non believer in VR. I thought it was a gimmick. Never really experienced VR until I watched a video of my favourite Youtuber (Callmekevin) Play Superhot and I was sold at that moment.I waited for Black Friday. Bought the Oculus Rift S (first time round got dog food but a week later I got the replacement) and Oh boy. I cant play 2d games the same anymore. I have ascended in gaming and honestly its amazing.The Oculus Rift should be everyones choice for their VR on a budget. (If you want to spend the money go for Index)People like to shut this headset down because its by Facebook. But this piece of tech is amazing and once its on your head, you’ll forget the world around you.My only downside is the audio but its not as bad as people make it out to be. (And there is an audio port that fixes this problem) I mostly play with the audio from the rift s and it just as immersive for me as using headphones (except in music games like Beatsaber)Another downside is the the fact that this headset is locked in terms of IPD. (I have the perfect distance of 64.5 so no issue)And also I want to point out that this screen isnt OLED but LCD. (But the index is also LCD and thats $1000) It makes the screen sharper and better than being able to see a better black. I have played elite dangerous on the Rift and honestly Ill take the better detail over OLED.Id honestly pick this over WMR (due to support for WMR in games arent that great) and the Vive (which is outdated and more expensive)The tracking is phenomenal with 99% accuracy and the fact you dont have base stations but cameras instead makes setting this bad boy up so easy and going into VR like as easy as going to bed.Set up took 10 mins and that was it.Great piece of tech and would 100% reccomend this headset to anyone and everyone
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 17 December 2019

one_reviews_text: Tried original rift. This has great head strap system. Comfortable. Easy to set up. Pass through feature is very useful. Use oculus tray tool (free download) to get even better results. Dcs is fantastic, flyinside sim is excellent( made for vr)., p3d4 and x plane less so. 360 vids are a bonus and interesting offshoot. Audio is poor so use your own.I was going to give 4 stars, but this is a fantastic piece of kit at this price and it’s not it’s fault I’m not running over a 4790k at 4.6 and a 1080 gfx card.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 December 2019

one_reviews_text: Gave me headaches 😃 works well with the PC as it is designed to do. Bought it mainly to use with Elite and project cars 2. Does give an added sense to gaming but for me it's just not quite there yet. Maybe in a couple of years. Build, graphics and sound all very good. The ability to map out your gaming floor area is very well implemented. Over all a good fun piece of kit just not worth it for me personally. Not over keen on the port view it gives but if you look past that 😁 fun can be had.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 25 February 2021
review_title: Well built good quality headset with a few drawbacks

one_reviews_text: I had the original oculus rift and I liked it but got bored eventually. My reasons? the god rays, low resolution, field of view, the cameras in my room. I saw this and immediately dismissed it as I saw the Quest had the higher resolution. I can tell you right now, NEVER go by specs on paper. The difference here is the LCD screen. I put this on and fell in love with VR all over again. The screen door is minimised. The reason it's less noticeable is the way LCD displays pixels. VR isn't perfect yet of course and the resolution here can still be improved. You want to notice the backgrounds being pixellated etc when you put this headset on but all you need to do to be blown away is boot up ROBO RECALL and look at the first elevator sequence. You will struggle to see screen door at all.The field of view is slightly larger than the original oculus if your IPD is average (mines is 61). There's no manual IPD which sucks but i can see how Oculus have tried to cram as much into their headsets with as low consumer price point as possible (hence why the Quest with the manual IPD and pentile display was released at the same time). It almost seems like Oculus are throwing out different displays and makeups to see what people prefer for generation 2.The software IPD does help if your IPD is slightly out of the normal range (mines is 61 and the sweet spot was a bit tricky. I changed the software IPD and now the sweet spot is fairly large). Text is remarkably easy to read in the fore front. Background a bit hard still but this is still a new technology. Tracking is perfect. The few times when tracking is lost is so minor, its worth losing the cameras and tripods. The refresh rate has dropped to 80hz. I'm extremely sensitive to lower refresh rates (60-70hz are impossible for me to view) but the 80 is absolutely fine.This is VR starting to get to the level I've waited for since "The Lawnmower Man". This is the first time I've genuinely been excited by the technology. This and the quest are amazing headsets tho I prefer this one because of the LCD screen. Some people prefer the pentiles but i love this.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 26 January 2020
review_title: This is VR starting to get good

one_reviews_text: It's really good as a budget vr headset but has its problems. The distance between lenses cannot be changed but does have a software based one so people with eyes very close or very far apart may want to get their ipd checked to see if they can use this product as it only supports 59 to 75 ipd. It has a foam rim that is glued on so hygiene won't be great if you plan to share the headset. My right controller has gone squeaky on the trigger. This headset makes up for these problems with it great resolution and refresh rate the camera tracking on it is not actually as bad as you'd expect for camera-based tracking of the controllers. If you dislike Facebook I do not recommend this product as they are making it required to have a Facebook account rest in peace Oculus accounts.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 20 March 2021
review_title: It's a great budget VR headset but if you don't have a ton of money to play with. Good

one_reviews_text: Ha sido mi primera vez en la RV de pc, y puedo decir que no me arrepiento de la compra, me ha llegado antes de lo previsto y estoy disfrutando como un enano y eso que solo tengo una gtx 960 OC y 4GB(en teoría el mínimo recomendado y va perfecta )Pros:-La calidad de las lentes, y de la pantalla LCD con subpíxeles RGB hace que se vea increíble, los colores son muy fieles pero el negro pierde algo de intensidad.- Super cómodas de instalar, las tengo conectadas al pc y es tan sencillo como ponérselas y listo.- El tracking es sublime, jugando al super Hot he hecho movimientos donde juraría que las cámaras no me estaban cogiendo los mandos, y no me ha dado ningún problema.- El ecosistema de oculus está súper optimizado, como dije incluso con mi gráfica no he tenido problemas de rendimiento, y tampoco en los juegos que he probado hasta ahora.- El sonido me ha sorprendido, había leído que a la gente era el punto que menos le gustaba, pero con mi fisionomía los altavoces caen en el lugar idóneo.Contras:- El material de la diadema, da bastante calor, y como estés jugando a un juego intenso se termina sudando.- La diadema es blandita, pero el peso cae demasiado sobre la cara, debajo de los ojos y molesta un poco. Imagino que esto también dependerá de la cara de cada uno.Por último, un caso aparte es el IPD, solo lo puedes regular por software, pero las lentes son fijas, yo he tenido la suerte de que tengo un IPD de 60, y puedo decir que lo veo perfecto. La medida ideal son 63, así que cuanto más te alejes más problemas podrías tener.Si estás dudando y tú IPD no está tan alejado, dudo que encuentres un visor de RV a este precio y con esta calidad.
review_date: Reviewed in Spain on 1 June 2019
review_title: El mejor visor de PC calidad/precio

one_reviews_text: Not a bad entry point for VR. Games made specifically for VR are still quite thin on the ground and for the most part unimpressive. You can get some decent experiences, GTA V with the VR mod is quite good. The technology isn't quite really up to par visually though, you will get a lesser visual but more immersive experience. Elite Dangerous is good with a Rift S. I suspect those looking for the seated sim experience will get the most out of this (the reason I bought it).Your mileage with apps like vorpx may vary, it can be somewhat effective, but don't expect too much from it, after all it's not official tailor made game support.Glasses wearers (like me) beware though there is not much clearance inside the headset even at maximum clearance. You may find your glasses in contact with the headset lens, increasing risk of lens damage and reducing comfort. I may try some custom prescription inserts and see how it fares then. They are however quite expensive and as you might expect not something you will be able to get from your typical high street opticians, you would need to go through a specialist online retailer.I also find the battery hungry controllers and oculus software particularly obnoxious. I am not interested at all using them flailing about like a muppet, I just want to use my mouse and keyboard. Which for Elite Dangerous for example you can. But when you first start up the oculus on a daily basis you have to go through the rigmarole of the guardian/area setup up software demanding attention, even if you turn it off, very annoying. I want to be able to just use my mouse with the oculus software ui.Ultimately this Tech still has a long way to go tbh and game developers still need to take the jump and support it fully, for it to reach it's undoubted potential.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 29 March 2021

one_reviews_text: After a short experience with the HTC Vive sold me on VR, I started looking at getting a second hand Vive. Eventually, though, I decided to get a Rift S when it was on sale for £350, and I'm glad I did.Setup is pretty quick and easy, aside from the Oculus software forcing you to sit through health and safety videos, the firmware update I had to do not pushing to the controllers so it was asking me to pair the controllers again when what I actually had to do was leave the configuration and update the controllers separately, and it not working with anything outside the Oculus store until you enable the "Unknown Sources" option.Visuals are good, just make sure to warm the headset up before putting it on so it doesn't steam up. No issues with ~66.5mm IPD, it does get a bit blurry towards the edges of the FoV but that's not IPD related, and it's still better than the Vive was. Haven't got any light bleed, but I can imagine it being an issue with smaller noses than mine. Also, while the lower refresh rate of 80 Hz might be a downgrade over the Vive and Rift, lower persistence means that there's less motion blur so it actually ends up being clearer and might even be better at preventing sickness.Speaking of sickness, that was an issue for the first couple of days, but after a week of short sessions that I stopped once I started feeling ill, it hasn't come back. Your experience may differ.The headset's decently comfortable if you take a few minutes to adjust everything. It's not going to feel weightless, and it will definitely press in on your head slightly, but you quickly forget about it until you take it off 3 hours later and see the small imprint it leaves around your eyes.Tracking is mostly fine. Haven't had the headset lose track of the room, but the controllers will occasionally fly off-screen under quick movements, or get stuck by your side/behind your back. It's infrequent enough that I can't complain much, but still something worth mentioning.And finally, the controllers. They're fine, only issue is needing to change the batteries every couple of weeks. I'd recommend a pair of AMVR grips so you don't have to hold onto them constantly, but then you won't be able to fit them back in the box and may want to buy a case/stand to store (the headset fits pretty much perfectly in PSVR cases).All in all, worth every penny.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 23 January 2020
review_title: Good visuals, decent comfort and mostly good tracking for a decent price

one_reviews_text: Was working reasonably well but then a health & safety message prevented further use. An old problem which Facebook appear to have failed to fix. Re-installing the software & setting up takes ages so I am returning for a full refund.Edit January 2020Several weeks on and with past problems resolved removing the need to return the Rift S I've been having a lot great VR experiences. Primarily with the P3D flight sim and Elite Horizons utilising Oculus tray tweaks there is no way I will be using my monitor except in low FPS situations.Lots of frustration to start with but once through the initial learning curve hugely rewarding.Excellent value for money.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 January 2020
review_title: Rift S stopped working within a month but now fixed & excellent value for money

one_reviews_text: Basically it didn’t work. If you get a faulty one, don’t expect to be able to return it to amazon you can’t, you have to go through the company. You go to their website and there is no box to say it’s faulty, so you have to say there is another reason for getting in touch, and then you get an email back saying “someone should be in touch within 2 working days”.... I’m sure not feeling good about this. Oh and did I mention it was my sons Christmas present, one very upset boy on Christmas Day..... moral of the story, I’ll never buy this sort of product again on Amazon.
review_date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 27 December 2019

one_reviews_text: tiene una calidad calidad aceptable en cuanto al precio que tiene, por lo que si eres un nuevo usuario de la realidad virtual no vas a tener ningún problema, Oculus lo ha hecho bien y tiene un precio bastante bien comedido. Lo que te van a brindar las Oculus Rift S es un ecosistema muy bien pulido y bien desarrollado. Por lo cual vamos a tener todo muy fácil a la hora de dar los primeros pasos.En cuanto al diseño está bastante bien acabado ya que es de plástico, no es feo pero ya que cada uno saque sus propias conclusiones, supongo que esto ya es un poquito más personal de cada uno. Eso sí no es un visor ligero, pesa bastante comparado con otros del mercado. El cable para el pc, es bastante gordo, más que en otros modelos que llama bastante la atención, que acaba en un Display port (no lleva HDMI) y un puerto USB 3.0, también incluye un adaptador mini display port por si lo necesitamos conectar a algún portátil.En cuanto a las lentes son las mismas que las que llevan las Oculus Quest, por lo que son de una calidad bastante importante, de hecho si tu IPD se ajusta al de las gafas tendrás un punto dulce casi del 100%, eso sí hay que colocárselas muy bien. si tu IPD se aleja demasiado de los 63 seguramente empezaras a ver los bordes turbios y tendrás problemas. Y es porque no tiene ajuste mecánico de IPD ya que solo tiene una pantalla.Tiene un Glare muy pequeño, que no molesta, en entornos con mucho contraste si que se nota pero jugando apenas se apreciaEn cuanto a la pantalla tiene una resolución de 2560x1440 es un panel LCD con RGB y se ve bastante bienEn cuanto al aro y la diadema, es muy importante el colocárnosla bien si no queremos tener problemas con el punto dulce, donde vemos todo nítido.
